cheatsheetvideos.quote: Alexa shares with us how she went in for her Class A permit and decided to get her Hazmat endorsement as a bonus!
Mark shares his feedback on his Class A CDL Cheat Sheet

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter a cab due to:
questions.answerB: Using the wrong type of fuel.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: A faulty exhaust system is a serious safety hazard. It may allow poisonous fumes to enter the vehicle's cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: When starting from a complete stop, a vehicle should:
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting vehicles behind you, you must ensure that your vehicle will not roll backward when you start moving forward from a stopped position.

questions.question: A safety valve is set to open at ____ pounds per square inch (psi).
questions.explanation: The safety valve protects air tanks and the rest of an air brake system from accumulating too much air pressure. The safety valve is usually set to open at 150 psi.

questions.question: If an air compressor is belt-driven, the belt should be routinely checked to ensure that it is:
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. Check the tightness of the belt and verify that it is in good condition.

questions.question: You will be denied a HazMat endorsement if:
questions.answerA: You are a resident of the state in which you are applying.
questions.answerB: You have no prior felony convictions.
questions.answerC: You are considered to pose a threat.
questions.explanation: You will be denied a hazardous materials endorsement, or lose an existing endorsement, if you renounce your U.S. citizenship; are not a lawful permanent U.S. resident; are wanted for, indicted for, or convicted of certain felonies; are judged mentally defective or are committed to a mental institution; or are deemed by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA) to pose a security threat.

questions.question: On a slippery surface, stopping distance:
questions.answerA: Is longer than on a regular driving surface.
questions.answerB: Is not as long as on a regular driving surface.
questions.answerC: Is about the same as on a regular driving surface.
questions.explanation: A vehicle's regular stopping distance increases on slippery surfaces because there is less available traction.

questions.question: If you have more than one license:
questions.answerC: You may get caught through the states' shared computer network.
questions.explanation: All states share driver information through a computerized database in order to prevent the issuance of multiple licenses to a single person. It is prohibited for a person to have more than one driver license.

questions.question: While driving, ____ generally holds spring brakes in place.
questions.explanation: While driving, spring brakes are generally held in place by air pressure. If the air pressure gets low enough, the springs will activate the brakes.

questions.question: If you are braking on dry pavement while traveling at 55 mph, how much distance will brake lag add to your overall stopping distance?
questions.explanation: The total stopping distance for vehicles equipped with air brakes is made up of four factors: perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. When braking at a speed of 55 mph while driving on dry pavement, the brake lag can add around 32 feet to the vehicle's total stopping distance.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Hop directly from their seat to the ground.
questions.answerB: Maintain at least one point of contact with their vehicle.
questions.answerC: Be turned to face their vehicle.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: Driving at night is:
questions.answerA: Safer than driving during the day.
questions.answerB: Just as safe as driving during the day.
questions.answerC: More dangerous than driving during the day.
questions.explanation: Driving at night is more dangerous than driving during the day because hazards become more difficult to see in the dark.

questions.question: To qualify for a CDL, which of the following is not an acceptable method for obtaining the minimum required training?
questions.answerA: Completing a certified course from an approved commercial driver training school
questions.answerB: Completing a course of commercial driver training as required by an employer
questions.answerC: Reading the official commercial driver's manual
questions.explanation: If you are applying for your first CDL, or you have not been commercially licensed for the past year, you must provide proof of completing a commercial driver training program from a state-approved training school or registered employer.

questions.question: If your wheels being to spin when accelerating on a poor traction surface, you should:
questions.answerB: Take your foot off the accelerator.
questions.explanation: If your drive wheels begin to spin while accelerating on a surface with poor traction, you should remove your foot from the accelerator.

questions.question: When it is difficult to see and you are traveling near other drivers, you should:
questions.explanation: Use your low beam headlights when traveling near other drivers at times when it is difficult to see, such as at dawn, at dusk, or in poor weather conditions. Using the high beam setting under certain conditions could make it difficult for other drivers to see.

questions.question: If a load is 40 feet long, it should be secured by at least ____ tie-downs.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: If mirrors are dirty before starting a trip:
questions.answerA: They will likely become clean after driving a short distance.
questions.answerB: It should not be a concern.
questions.answerC: They should be cleaned before the vehicle is driven.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, be sure to check the mirrors and windshield for dirt and anything else that could interfere with your ability to see. Clean them as necessary.

questions.question: While driving, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Not be concerned with what is happening on the sides of their vehicle.
questions.answerB: Be concerned with what is happening on all sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with what is happening behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Scan the road ahead and make regular checks of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while you are driving.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation, you must inform your employer:
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any kind of traffic violation in any type of vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the incident. You must also inform your motor vehicle licensing agency within 30 days if the incident happened in another jurisdiction. This rule does not apply to parking infractions.

questions.question: Hanging meat in a refrigerated truck:
questions.answerA: Is a good way for inexperienced drivers to gain experience.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: Emergency equipment in a vehicle is:
questions.answerA: Only required for vehicles that are transporting hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should check for emergency equipment, including spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: A driver may restart a period of seven or eight consecutive days on duty:
questions.explanation: In Washington State, there are limits to the number of hours a driver may drive during a seven- or eight-day period. A commercial driver who reaches the end of a duty period may begin a new seven- or eight-day period after taking at least 34 consecutive hours off.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: When completing a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.answerB: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 must have:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997, and other vehicles with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1998, must be equipped with anti-lock brakes.

questions.question: When traveling down a steep downgrade:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be used.
questions.answerB: The vehicle should be placed in a low gear and the driver should use engine braking.
questions.answerC: The driver should continually downshift instead of using the brakes.
questions.explanation: On long and/or steep downgrades, you should primarily use engine braking to control the speed of your vehicle. Use your brakes only as a supplement to this effect.

questions.question: When approaching your vehicle as part of a pre-trip inspection, seeing fresh oil underneath the vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle, you should check under the vehicle for fresh oil, coolant, grease, or fuel leaks. Spotting any of these before a trip is a cause for concern.

questions.question: Hydroplaning usually occurs:
questions.answerB: When driving at speeds slower than 15 mph.
questions.answerC: In areas where water collects on the road.
questions.explanation: Hydroplaning occurs on surfaces where water has collected. If there is enough water, vehicles can hydroplane at speeds as low as 30 mph. Hydroplaning becomes more likely if tires are under-inflated or if the tread is worn.

questions.question: If a vehicle's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is malfunctioning:
questions.answerA: The vehicle will have no brakes.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will still be able to brake.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will likely travel faster than usual.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) intervenes to reduce brake pressure if there is a risk of wheel lockup. If the ABS isn't working, the vehicle's basic braking functions are not affected. A driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal manner.

questions.question: What can happen if the air pressure gets too low in an air brake system?
questions.explanation: Pressing and releasing the brake pedal unnecessarily can let air out of the braking system faster than the compressor can replace it. Air brakes may cease to work effectively if the pressure becomes too low.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be score you on specific driving maneuvers as well as on your general driving behavior. You must drive in a safe and responsible manner; obey all traffic signs, signals, and laws; and not cause an accident or commit a moving violation.

questions.question: On a slippery road, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Make turns as quickly as possible.
questions.explanation: Under slippery conditions, you should drive slowly and smoothly. Make turns as gently as possible and do not pass other vehicles unless you have to.

questions.question: If you are confronted with an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerB: Try to stay in their way.
questions.explanation: The best thing to do when confronted with an aggressive driver is to get out of their way, if possible. Avoid making eye contact, which could further provoke the driver. Ignore any hand gestures made by the driver.

questions.question: If asked by a law enforcement officer to take a test to determine your blood alcohol concentration (BAC):
questions.answerA: You can refuse to take the test without a penalty.
questions.answerB: You can refuse taking the test but will be required to pay a $50 fine.
questions.answerC: You will lose your CDL if you refuse to take the test.
questions.explanation: Most states have an Implied Consent Law, which means that by driving a vehicle on the state's roads, you have agreed to undergo a drug or alcohol test if a police officer asks you to do so. If you refuse to submit to a test, you will lose your operating privileges. Make sure you are aware of the laws for every state in which you drive.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, it is important to maintain ____ with your vehicle at all times.
questions.explanation: As you exit your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: An encroachment is when:
questions.answerA: A driver does not appear for their scheduled basic skills test.
questions.answerB: A vehicle touches an exercise boundary line during the basic skills test.
questions.answerC: A driver fails one section of the basic skills test.
questions.explanation: An encroachment during the basic vehicle control skills test is when an exercise boundary line is touched or crossed by any portion of the applicant's vehicle. Every encroachment will be counted as an error.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to cover cargo?
questions.answerA: To protect people from spilled cargo
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather
questions.answerC: To protect the cargo from animals
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: Skids caused by over-acceleration can usually be resolved by:
questions.answerA: Removing your foot from the accelerator.
questions.explanation: A skid caused by over-acceleration can be resolved simply by removing your foot from the accelerator. Skids of this nature happen most frequently on surfaces covered in snow or ice.

questions.question: When asked to make a lane change during the driving test, you should:
questions.answerA: Make the change as soon as the examiner asks, without looking.
questions.answerB: Use your turn signal and change lanes when safe.
questions.answerC: Make the lane change as quickly as possible, even if that means cutting off another driver.
questions.explanation: You will be asked to change lanes during the on-road driving test. When the examiner asks you to do this, you should make the necessary traffic checks and use the proper signals before changing lanes.

questions.question: A CMV should:
questions.answerA: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless it is being used to transport hazardous materials.
questions.answerB: Not have a fire extinguisher, unless it will be traveling through remote areas.
questions.answerC: Have a fire extinguisher and other emergency equipment.
questions.explanation: All commercial motor vehicles are required to be equipped with the proper emergency equipment. This may include spare electrical fuses; three red reflective triangles, six fuses, or three liquid burning flares; and at least one properly charged and rated fire extinguisher.

questions.question: If transporting logs, a ____ light needs to be placed on the most extended point of the load.
questions.explanation: When hauling items like poles or logs, a red light must be placed at the most extended point of the load. This light must be a combination light visible from the back and both sides.

questions.question: A Class 1 hazardous material is:
questions.explanation: The first hazardous materials class includes explosives such as ammunition, dynamite, and fireworks.

questions.question: If taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take the test again on a route that does include a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your on-road driving test route does not include a railroad crossing, you may be asked to explain and demonstrate the proper railroad crossing procedures to the examiner at a simulated location.

questions.question: A wig wag is:
questions.answerB: A tube that carries air to the brakes.
questions.answerC: A type of air brake system.
questions.explanation: Vehicles with air brakes are required to be equipped with a low pressure warning device. A wig wag is a type of low air pressure warning device. This device drops a mechanical arm into the driver's view if the pressure in the tanks drops to a level between 55 and 75 psi.

questions.question: What should you do if your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks?
questions.answerB: Get out of the vehicle and call for assistance.
questions.answerC: Continue trying to get your vehicle off the tracks until you are successful.
questions.explanation: If your CMV gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should immediately leave the vehicle and get away from the tracks. Check the signposts or signal housing at the crossing for emergency contact information and call 911, or another appropriate emergency number.

questions.question: If your license to operate a personal vehicle is revoked or suspended:
questions.answerA: You can get a hardship license to operate a CMV.
questions.answerB: You cannot get a hardship license to operate a CMV.
questions.answerC: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.explanation: If your license to operate your personal vehicle is revoked, canceled, or suspended, you may not obtain a hardship license to operate a CMV.

questions.question: When starting an engine, oil pressure should come up to a normal level:
questions.explanation: Look at your truck's gauges when starting the engine. The oil pressure in an engine should come up to a normal level within seconds of the vehicle's engine being started.

questions.question: When completing an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull straight forward, then drive straight back.
questions.answerB: Drive straight back, then pull forward to the left.
questions.answerC: Pull straight forward, then back to the right.
questions.explanation: If you are asked to complete an offset back/right parking maneuver, you should first pull straight forward, then back up to the right. Your vehicle must be parked completely within the boundaries of the parking space.

questions.question: Dual tires should:
questions.answerA: Always come into contact with one another.
questions.answerB: Come into contact with one another fairly regularly.
questions.answerC: Not come into contact with one another.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should verify that your dual tires do not come into contact with one another, or with any other part of the vehicle.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a recommended way to spot potential signs of trouble?
questions.answerC: Checking critical items only at the beginning and end of a trip
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly make checks to ensure that your vehicle is operating properly. Check the instrument panel and gauges; look at your mirrors; and examine the tires, cargo, and lights. Use all of your senses and be alert for anything that could be an early indication of trouble.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located inside:
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: When starting from a complete stop, a vehicle should:
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting vehicles behind you, you must ensure that your vehicle will not roll backward when you start moving forward from a stopped position.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a warning sign of fatigue?
questions.explanation: Potential warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing, frequent blinking, or heavy eyelids; yawning repeatedly or rubbing your eyes; daydreaming; wandering or disconnected thoughts; trouble remembering the last few miles you've driven; missing exits or traffic signs; having trouble keeping your head up; drifting from your lane; following too closely; hitting a shoulder rumble strip; or feeling restless and irritable.

questions.question: While driving, if you notice anything that affects safety or could lead to mechanical problems, you should:
questions.answerA: Wait to see if the problem goes away.
questions.answerB: Include the concerns in your written report.
questions.answerC: Try to fix the issue yourself.
questions.explanation: After finishing a day of driving, you may have to complete a written report on the condition of your vehicle. Be sure to mention anything that could affect safety or lead to mechanical breakdown.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, if one air system is very low on pressure:
questions.answerA: None of the brakes will work at all.
questions.answerB: Either the front or rear brakes will not be fully operable.
questions.answerC: There is usually no noticeable effect.
questions.explanation: In a dual air brake system, either the front or rear brakes will not be fully operable if one of the air systems gets too low on pressure. If the air pressure in either tank gets too low while you are driving, you should exit the road and park as soon as possible.

questions.question: If convicted of a traffic violation in your personal car:
questions.answerB: Your CDL will not be affected.
questions.answerC: Law enforcement will tell your employer.
questions.explanation: If you are convicted of any traffic violations while driving any vehicle, you must notify your employer within 30 days of the conviction. This rule excludes parking violations.

questions.question: For a basic vehicle control skills test, you are expected to be able to:
questions.answerB: Weave between a line of cones.
questions.explanation: Maneuvers that may be included in the basic vehicle control skills test include straight line backing, offset back/right parking, offset back/left parking, driver side parallel parking, conventional parallel parking, and alley docking.

questions.question: Water that has collected on a roadway can cause:
questions.explanation: The risk of hydroplaning begins when water has collected on the surface of a road.

questions.question: Using the brakes creates heat. If too much heat is produced:
questions.answerB: The brakes may squeak more than usual.
questions.explanation: Brakes are designed to take a lot of heat, but drivers should not rely solely on the brakes to slow their vehicle. Brakes may fade and lose their ability to slow down the vehicle if they become too hot, so drivers should also rely on the engine braking effect.

questions.question: When pulled over to the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely on your taillights to alert other motorists to your presence.
questions.answerC: Use your four-way emergency flashers to alert other motorists to your presence.
questions.explanation: When stopped on the side of the road, be sure to turn on your vehicle's four-way emergency flashers, especially during times of lowered visibility. Place warning devices within 10 minutes of being stopped.

questions.question: As part of a pre-trip inspection, you should look for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Tires with too much air pressure.
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is tread depth of at least 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch in grooves on the other tires. Be sure that your tires are not too worn, are not cracked, have proper air pressure, and are all equally sized.

questions.question: Cargo with a high center of gravity:
questions.answerA: Can make a vehicle likely to tip over.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of tire failure?
questions.explanation: If you experience tire failure, you may hear the loud "bang" sound of a blowout or feel a heavy thumping or vibration in your vehicle. If steering begins to feel heavy, or if the rear of your vehicle begins to fishtail, you should stop to check your tires.

questions.question: An empty truck:
questions.answerA: Requires a shorter stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerB: Requires a longer stopping distance than a full truck.
questions.answerC: Takes the same distance to stop as a full truck.
questions.explanation: Empty trucks require longer stopping distances than full trucks because they have less traction available.

questions.question: Watching the road ahead of you:
questions.answerA: Allows you time to make a plan to avoid an upcoming hazard.
questions.answerB: Is not encouraged as it distracts you from driving.
questions.answerC: Is only important when traveling in congested traffic.
questions.explanation: Always watch for hazards on the road ahead. Doing this will allow you time to react to hazards before meeting them.

questions.question: In cool weather, as the temperature begins to rise and ice begins to melt:
questions.answerA: It is usually safe to drive.
questions.answerB: The road will become even more slippery.
questions.explanation: As the temperature begins to rise and ice on the road begins to melt, the road surface will often become even more slippery. Water from the slight melting will sit on top of the ice, decreasing the available traction even more. Always decrease your speed and drive with caution when traveling on slippery surfaces.

questions.question: Do not base your decision to shift gears on:
questions.answerC: The actions of the vehicle next to you.
questions.explanation: One way to know when it is time to shift gears is to learn your vehicle's operating rpm range. You should shift up when your engine reaches the top of that range. You can also learn which speeds each gear is good for and shift up based on your speedometer.

questions.question: Hanging meat in a refrigerated truck:
questions.answerA: Is a good way for inexperienced drivers to gain experience.
questions.explanation: An operator should drive with care when transporting a cargo of hanging meat. Such a load is unstable, both because it has a high center of gravity and because the swinging of the meat can affect the driver's handling of the vehicle.

questions.question: How long must an applicant hold a CLP before they may take the required skills tests?
questions.explanation: You must hold a Commercial Learner Permit (CLP) for a minimum of 14 days before you are permitted to take the required skills tests.

questions.question: What should happen before the air pressure in an air brake system tank falls below 55 psi?
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be unable to shift out of gear.
questions.explanation: The low air pressure warning signal must activate before the air supply pressure drops below 55 psi in the air tank. If the warning signal does not turn on when being tested during an inspection, the vehicle is not safe to drive.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: If driving on a surface with poor traction, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: So that they do not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: To avoid a loss of control, you should accelerate slowly when driving in poor-traction conditions, such as rain or snow.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: You may be an aggressive driver if you:
questions.answerB: Slow down and maintain a reasonable following distance.
questions.answerC: Make hand gestures that could anger other drivers.
questions.explanation: Avoid being an aggressive driver by being realistic about your travel time, making allowance for delays, maintaining reasonable following distances, and not making hand gestures that could anger another driver.

questions.question: Maintaining a cushion of space between your vehicle and the vehicle ahead is:
questions.answerA: Not encouraged, as it slows the flow of traffic.
questions.answerB: Encouraged, as it allows you time to react to unexpected hazards.
questions.answerC: Only encouraged if you are traveling with a passenger.
questions.explanation: For safe driving, it is essential that you maintain cushions of space on all sides of your vehicle. This helps to ensure that you will have time to take appropriate action if a problem arises.

questions.question: The ____ between an air compressor and reservoir tank prevents air from escaping if the air compressor has a leak.
questions.explanation: A one-way check valve is required to be between an air compressor and the first main reservoir. This valve prevents air from escaping the system if the air compressor develops a leak.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pressed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop the vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: You should maintain at least ____ of following distance per every 10 feet of your vehicle when you are traveling more slowly than 40 mph.
questions.explanation: At speeds below 40 mph, you should allow at least one second of following distance for every 10 feet of your vehicle. Follow the same formula when traveling at faster speeds, then add one additional second to your following distance. Remember that larger vehicles require more space to stop than smaller vehicles.

questions.question: If an unusual noise or feeling occurs in a vehicle while it is being driven, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle does alright until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check the situation to determine the proper solution.
questions.explanation: If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything while driving that does not feel right, you should have it checked out.

questions.question: Cargo inside a trailer:
questions.answerA: Does not need to be secured.
questions.answerB: Should be stacked no more than three feet high.
questions.answerC: Should be secured to prevent movement.
questions.explanation: Cargo inside a trailer must be secured appropriately to prevent it from shifting in transit.

questions.question: If turning to avoid a hazard:
questions.answerB: You should not brake as it may cause the wheels to lock.
questions.explanation: You should not brake while making a quick turn to avoid a hazard. Doing so could cause your wheels to lock and make your vehicle skid out of control.

questions.question: Poisonous fumes can enter a cab due to:
questions.answerB: Using the wrong type of fuel.
questions.answerC: A lack of oil in the engine.
questions.explanation: A faulty exhaust system is a serious safety hazard. It may allow poisonous fumes to enter the vehicle's cab or sleeper berth.

questions.question: The two markings on a front brake limiting valve usually read:
questions.explanation: Some vehicles with air brake systems manufactured before 1975 have a front brake limiting valve with "normal" and "slippery" settings.

questions.question: If youâ€™re unfamiliar with the area in which you must back up, you should:
questions.answerA: Get out of your vehicle and walk around the area to become more familiar with it.
questions.answerB: Not use both side mirrors because it can be distracting.
questions.answerC: Wait for someone else to back up in the area so you can see how they do it.
questions.explanation: Before backing up, you should get out of your vehicle and look at your line of travel. Check your clearance to the sides and overhead.

questions.question: Poor weight balance:
questions.explanation: Poorly balanced cargo can cause a vehicle to be difficult to handle. Keep weight distribution in mind when loading cargo.

questions.question: Hanging meat as cargo is usually:
questions.explanation: A cargo of hanging meat can be very unstable, both because the meat swings about in transit and because its center of gravity is high.

questions.question: What is the left lane rule?
questions.answerA: Heavy vehicles must only be driven in the left lane of a road with three lanes traveling in one direction.
questions.answerB: Heavy vehicles may only be driven in the left lane of a road with three lanes traveling in one direction if making a left turn.
questions.answerC: Heavy vehicles cannot be driven in the left lane of a three lane road for any purpose.
questions.explanation: Washington State's left lane rule states that no vehicle or combination weighing over 10,000 pounds may be driven in the left lane of a limited-access road with three or more lanes traveling in one direction, unless preparing to make a left turn.

questions.question: The parking brake in a newer vehicle is applied by:
questions.answerA: Moving a lever to the right.
questions.explanation: In newer vehicles with air brakes, the parking brake is controlled by a yellow, diamond-shaped knob. The driver should pull the knob outward to apply the parking brakes and push the knob inward to release them.

questions.question: If mirrors are dirty before starting a trip:
questions.answerA: They will likely become clean after driving a short distance.
questions.answerB: It should not be a concern.
questions.answerC: They should be cleaned before the vehicle is driven.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, be sure to check the mirrors and windshield for dirt and anything else that could interfere with your ability to see. Clean them as necessary.

questions.question: Dual tires should:
questions.answerA: Always come into contact with one another.
questions.answerB: Come into contact with one another fairly regularly.
questions.answerC: Not come into contact with one another.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle, you should verify that your dual tires do not come into contact with one another, or with any other part of the vehicle.

questions.question: On any upgrade, gravity will:
questions.explanation: A vehicle will be slowed down by gravity on any uphill grade. You may need to switch to a lower gear to climb a steep grade.

questions.question: When accelerating on a surface with poor traction, such as a wet road, a driver should:
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about the pavement.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under conditions that create poor traction.

questions.question: Having ABS on only one axle:
questions.answerB: Still allows you additional control when braking.
questions.answerC: Slows the vehicle, but cannot stop it.
questions.explanation: If you have an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) equipped on only the tractor, only the trailer, or only one axle, you will still have more control over the vehicle when braking than you would without ABS. You should brake normally.

questions.question: Parked delivery trucks may be hazardous because:
questions.answerB: People are often in a hurry when exiting such trucks and may not look for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Packages often fall out of the trucks and into the road.
questions.explanation: Passing parked delivery or postal trucks can be dangerous because the driver may be in a hurry and pull into traffic without warning, or may they suddenly step out of the vehicle without checking for other traffic.

questions.question: Header boards:
questions.answerB: Protect drivers from being hit by cargo.
questions.answerC: Protect drivers' heads when they are entering the cab of a truck.
questions.explanation: A header board protects a driver from moving cargo in the event of a crash or emergency stop.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they make toward you. Avoid making eye contact with the other driver and do not try to race them.

questions.question: Rims with welding repairs:
questions.answerB: Are acceptable to be used on tires in the rear of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Are acceptable to be used if carrying a light load.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims with welding repairs are never safe to use.

questions.question: The Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) does not need to include which of the following?
questions.answerC: Number of meals eaten by the driver
questions.explanation: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include information about the distance traveled by a vehicle and the amount of fuel purchased. The required distance information includes the origin and destination points of the trip and the Vehicle Identification Number.

questions.question: A vehicle loaded with dirt or sand must be covered if:
questions.answerB: Fewer than six inches of freeboard are maintained.
questions.answerC: The driver has held their license for less than one year.
questions.explanation: In Washington State, a vehicle with a settled load of dirt, sand, or gravel that does not maintain at least six inches of freeboard must have a cover over the load.

questions.question: The use of a hand-held mobile device while driving is:
questions.answerB: Acceptable if weather conditions are clear.
questions.explanation: Using a hand-held mobile telephone while operating a CMV is both illegal and dangerous.

questions.question: Rust around wheel nuts may mean:
questions.explanation: Rust around wheel nuts may mean that they are loose. Check the tightness of the nuts if you see any rust in the area.

questions.question: When making a left turn, you should start the turn:
questions.answerA: Before reaching the center of the intersection.
questions.answerB: No sooner than the center of the intersection.
questions.answerC: After your rear wheels have passed the center of the intersection.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn, you should wait until you reach the center of the intersection before actually beginning to turn. Due to off-tracking, the left side of your vehicle could hit another driver if you begin turning too early.

questions.question: When accelerating on a surface with poor traction, such as a wet road, a driver should:
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about the pavement.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under conditions that create poor traction.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can help drivers see a larger area.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: ____ make up the emergency brake system.
questions.answerA: Only parts of the parking brake system
questions.answerB: Only parts of the service brake system
questions.answerC: Parts of the parking and service brake systems
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, there are three different braking systems: a service brake system, a parking brake system, and an emergency brake system. The emergency brake system uses parts of both the parking and service brake systems.

questions.question: Failing to drain air tanks could result in:
questions.answerA: Water accumulations freezing and causing brake failure.
questions.answerC: Too much air collecting in the tanks.
questions.explanation: In an air brake system, the air tanks must be periodically drained to remove accumulations of water and compressor oil. If water is not removed, it could freeze in cold weather and cause brake failure.

questions.question: What is the maximum legal weight to be placed on a single axle?
questions.explanation: The allowable gross weight of a bus or truck depends on its tire size, the number of axles, and the spacing of axles (or axle groups). In Washington State, the weight of a commercial vehicle is limited to no more than 20,000 pounds on any single axle.

questions.question: If driving so slowly that you could impede other drivers, you should:
questions.answerB: Drive while using your four-way flashers.
questions.explanation: If you must drive so slowly that you will impede the flow of traffic, you should turn on your four-way flashers to alert drivers behind you (as long as local laws allow the use of flashers).

questions.question: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, a separate air tank can be used:
questions.answerA: To make the air brakes work more effectively.
questions.answerB: To temporarily release the spring brakes.
questions.answerC: To charge the brakes on the rear trailer.
questions.explanation: In a vehicle with dual parking control valves, there is a separate air tank that can be used to temporarily release the spring brakes if they have been activated due to low air pressure. Pushing in the proper control will release the spring brakes for a short period of time, allowing the driver to move the vehicle in an emergency.

questions.question: What is brake lag?
questions.answerA: The time required for the brakes to work after the brake pedal is pressed
questions.answerB: The distance between the brake pedal and the floor
questions.answerC: The amount of air pressure used to stop the vehicle
questions.explanation: Because air takes time to flow through the air lines to the brakes, air brakes cannot begin working instantly. There is often a brake lag of at least one-half of a second between the moment the brake pedal is pressed and the moment the brakes begin to work.

questions.question: A truck tractor built after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: Black ice is:
questions.explanation: Black ice is a layer of ice that is thin and clear enough for the road to be visible through it. The surface will look like a wet road. Always be alert to black ice if the road looks wet when the temperature is below freezing.

questions.question: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, your best hope to stop is to:
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail on a downgrade, you will have to look outside your vehicle for a way to stop. Using an escape ramp is the safest way to stop your vehicle.

questions.question: While still below the legal limit, a driver operating a CMV with a detectable amount of alcohol in their system will:
questions.answerA: Result in an out-of-service order for two hours.
questions.answerB: Result in an out-of-service order for 10 hours.
questions.answerC: Result in an out-of-service order for 24 hours.
questions.explanation: If you are found to have any detectable amount of alcohol in your system while operating a CMV but your blood alcohol concentration (BAC) is still below the legal limit of 0.04 percent, you will be put out-of-service for 24 hours. It is both illegal and dangerous to operate a motor vehicle while under the influence of alcohol.

questions.question: Not using a safety belt while driving:
questions.explanation: You must always wear a safety belt while operating a commercial motor vehicle. Driving a CMV without being properly restrained by a safety belt is both illegal and dangerous.

questions.question: The air storage tanks:
questions.answerA: Hold only enough air for one braking cycle.
questions.answerB: Hold enough air for the brakes to be used several times if the compressor stops working.
questions.answerC: Do not hold air unless there is an emergency.
questions.explanation: The air storage tanks in an air brake system store compressed air to be used for braking. They hold enough air for the brakes to still be used several times if the compressor stops working.

questions.question: Braking mechanisms are located inside:
questions.explanation: Drum brakes are attached to the wheels and located on the axles of a vehicle. The braking mechanisms that cause the vehicle to stop can be found inside of a drum brake.

questions.question: Bracing is used to:
questions.answerA: Make items stand taller in a trailer.
questions.answerB: Prevent items from moving in a trailer.
questions.answerC: Make it easier to unload items from a trailer.
questions.explanation: Blocking and bracing are used to prevent cargo from shifting in transit. Blocking is used in the front, in the back, and on the sides of a piece of cargo to prevent movement. Bracing prevents movement by reaching from the upper portion of a piece of cargo to the floor and sides of the cargo compartment.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system:
questions.answerA: Can allow poisonous fumes to enter the cabin.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system can let poisonous fumes into a vehicle's cab or sleeper berth. Be sure to inspect your exhaust system for any loose, broken, or missing parts.

questions.question: ABS brakes:
questions.answerC: Prevent your vehicle from accelerating when going uphill.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: When stopping in an emergency situation, you should:
questions.answerA: Veer your trailer to the right and stop.
questions.answerC: Veer your trailer to the left and stop.
questions.explanation: If you need to make an emergency stop, you can use either the controlled braking method or the stab braking method. It's important to brake in a way that keeps your vehicle in a straight line but will still allow you to turn if necessary.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on specific driving maneuvers, as well as your general driving behavior.

questions.question: Friction in an S-cam brake is caused when the brake shoes and linings:
questions.answerA: Press against the outside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Press against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.explanation: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings push against the inside of the drum. The friction in the drums will slow and stop the vehicle.

questions.question: When exiting a vehicle, it is important to maintain ____ with your vehicle at all times.
questions.explanation: As you exit your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: When driving in fog, you should:
questions.explanation: It is best not to avoid driving in fog. However, if you must drive under foggy conditions, be sure to decrease your speed.

questions.question: Brake linings should be:
questions.explanation: Brake linings should not be loose or soaked with oil or grease. They shouldn't be dangerously thin.

questions.question: When pulled over to the side of the road, you should:
questions.answerA: Rely on your taillights to alert other motorists to your presence.
questions.answerC: Use your four-way emergency flashers to alert other motorists to your presence.
questions.explanation: When stopped on the side of the road, be sure to turn on your vehicle's four-way emergency flashers, especially during times of lowered visibility. Place warning devices within 10 minutes of being stopped.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from being loaded too high.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from being unloaded too quickly.
questions.explanation: Blocking is used in the front, in the back, and/or on the sides of a piece of cargo to keep it from sliding while the vehicle is in motion.

questions.question: A driver can rely on front wheel braking to work:
questions.answerC: Under all conditions, except for snow.
questions.explanation: Front wheel braking is effective under all road conditions. It is unlikely that you will experience a front wheel skid, even on ice.

questions.question: If a load is 40 feet long, it should be secured by at least ____ tie-downs.
questions.explanation: Cargo should be restrained by at least one tie-down for every 10 feet of cargo. However, all cargo should have at least two tie-downs, no matter the size of the cargo.

questions.question: What is the legal length limit for double-trailer combinations?
questions.explanation: In Washington State, a double-trailer combination may not exceed 61 feet in length.

questions.question: When trying to put out an electrical fire, you should:
questions.explanation: B:C fire extinguishers are designed to work on electrical fires and burning liquids. Don't pour water on an electrical fire.

questions.question: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on in a vehicle with air brakes, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Test the brakes while driving, but continue driving if nothing seems wrong.
questions.answerC: Drive with the hazard lights activated.
questions.explanation: If the low air pressure warning signal comes on while you are operating a vehicle with air brakes, you should stop and safely park the vehicle as soon as possible. It is essential that you are able to stop safely while you still have some braking power remaining.

questions.question: If you are driving at a reduced speed in a construction zone when you spot a construction worker near the road, you should:
questions.explanation: Always decrease your speed when traveling through a construction area. Slow down even further if there are workers on or near the roadway.

questions.question: When parked on a flat surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use wheel chocks to prevent your vehicle from moving.
questions.answerC: Use wheel chocks, but only if you have applied the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When parking on a level surface, you should use wheel chocks. If the vehicle is not equipped with spring brakes, this is essential to prevent the trailer from moving.

questions.question: Parked delivery trucks may be hazardous because:
questions.answerB: People are often in a hurry when exiting such trucks and may not look for other vehicles.
questions.answerC: Packages often fall out of the trucks and into the road.
questions.explanation: Passing parked delivery or postal trucks can be dangerous because the driver may be in a hurry and pull into traffic without warning, or may they suddenly step out of the vehicle without checking for other traffic.

questions.question: Rough acceleration:
questions.answerA: Is a good way to stay awake on long trips.
questions.explanation: Rough acceleration can cause mechanical damage, so be sure to accelerate smoothly and gradually.

questions.question: By beginning a left turn before reaching the center of an intersection, you:
questions.answerA: Will likely complete the turn satisfactorily.
questions.answerB: May hit other vehicles with the left side of your vehicle.
questions.answerC: Can expect other drivers to move their vehicles to accommodate your turn.
questions.explanation: When planning to turn left at an intersection, make sure you have reached the center of the intersection before beginning the turn. If you turn too soon, off-tracking may cause the left side of your vehicle to hit another vehicle.

questions.question: When driving a truck requiring a CDL:
questions.answerA: You do not need to wear a seat belt.
questions.answerB: You are required to wear a seat belt, but only if transporting more than 500 pounds of cargo.
questions.answerC: You must always wear a seat belt.
questions.explanation: You must be properly restrained by a safety belt at all times when driving a commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: What helps prevent wheel lockup when braking?
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent wheel lockup while brakes are being applied.

questions.question: One way to prevent drowsiness while driving is to:
questions.answerC: Get adequate sleep the night before the trip.
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness. Exercising regularly can increase your energy levels and make you less likely to become tired while driving.

questions.question: To stay alert while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Eat a heavy meal before beginning your trip.
questions.answerC: Ride with a second person who can share driving responsibilities.
questions.explanation: Splitting driving responsibilities with a second driver lowers the chance that either of you will drive while fatigued. You can also reduce the risk of fatigue by avoiding heavy foods and keeping the interior of the cab cool.

questions.question: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should:
questions.answerB: Pull over and figure out what's wrong.
questions.explanation: If the coolant temperature gauge goes above the highest safe temperature, you should stop driving as soon as possible and try to figure out what is wrong. There could be an issue in your vehicle that could lead to engine failure and possibly a fire.

questions.question: What is the Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR)?
questions.answerA: The weight stated by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle
questions.answerB: The maximum weight that can be pulled by a vehicle
questions.answerC: The minimum weight that can be hauled by a vehicle
questions.explanation: A Gross Vehicle Weight Rating (GVWR) is the value specified by the manufacturer as the loaded weight of a single vehicle.

questions.question: To use the controlled braking method, you should:
questions.answerB: Apply your brakes as firmly as possible without locking the wheels.
questions.explanation: Controlled braking is the method of applying a vehicle's brakes as hard as possible without locking the wheels. A driver should keep steering wheel movements very small if braking while using this method.

questions.question: During an applied leakage test, what is the maximum leakage rate that is safe for a single vehicle with air brakes?
questions.explanation: It is important to know the maximum air loss rate that is safe for your specific vehicle. A single vehicle with air brakes should have a leakage rate no higher than 3 psi in a minute during an applied leakage test.

questions.question: When braking with ABS, you should:
questions.answerC: Brake harder than you would with a different braking system.
questions.explanation: When braking a vehicle equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS), you should not brake any differently than you would if driving a vehicle with a different braking system.

questions.question: When parking, you should not use the parking brake if:
questions.answerC: There is snow on the ground.
questions.explanation: If your brakes are hot after coming down a steep grade, you should not use your parking brake when parking. Let your brakes cool before applying the parking brake or risk damaging the brakes.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, air pressure should build from 85 to 100 psi within ____ seconds.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: Who is responsible for the safe operation of a vehicle?
questions.explanation: The person driving a vehicle is responsible for its safe operation. Be sure to perform routine vehicle inspections before operating a commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: When itâ€™s difficult to see, such as at dawn or dusk, a driver can increase their vehicle's visibility by:
questions.explanation: When driving at dawn, at dusk, or in inclement weather, you should use your headlights on their low beam setting to increase your visibility.

questions.question: When approaching your vehicle as part of a pre-trip inspection, seeing fresh oil underneath the vehicle is:
questions.explanation: When approaching your vehicle, you should check under the vehicle for fresh oil, coolant, grease, or fuel leaks. Spotting any of these before a trip is a cause for concern.

questions.question: What do air brakes use to make the brakes work?
questions.explanation: Many large CMVs are equipped with air brakes. An air braking system uses compressed air to operate.

questions.question: When loading a trailer, weight should be:
questions.answerC: Placed as far to the left as possible.
questions.explanation: Cargo with a high center of gravity makes a vehicle more likely to tip over than cargo with a low center of gravity. For this reason, it is important that the weight of cargo be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: When are people usually the least alert?
questions.explanation: Most drivers are the least alert at night, especially after midnight. Therefore, crashes due to fatigued driving are more likely at night than any other time of day.

questions.question: The minimum acceptable tread depth for rear tires is:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: When pulled off on the side of the road:
questions.answerA: A driver should keep the driverâ€™s side door open.
questions.answerB: A driver should turn on the emergency flashers.
questions.answerC: The driver should wave their arms.
questions.explanation: If you must stop on the side of the road, make sure to use your four-way emergency flashers. This is particularly important at night.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a reason to cover cargo?
questions.answerA: To protect people from spilled cargo
questions.answerB: To protect the cargo from weather
questions.answerC: To keep the cargo a secret
questions.explanation: You should cover your cargo to protect people from the cargo if it spills, as well as to protect the cargo from the weather.

questions.question: A dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Consists of two separate air brake systems that share a single set of controls.
questions.answerB: Is a single air brake system with two different sets of controls.
questions.answerC: Consists of one air brake system for the left side of the truck and one system for the right side of the truck, each with its own set of controls.
questions.explanation: A dual air brake system is made up of two separate air brake systems. The systems share a single set of brake controls, but each has its own air tanks, hoses, and lines. One system typically operates the regular brakes on the rear axle or axles while the other system operates the regular brakes on the front axle.

questions.question: A jogger wearing a stereo headset:
questions.answerA: Is probably aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerB: May not be aware of what is happening around them.
questions.answerC: Can hear the sounds of traffic.
questions.explanation: Be careful around pedestrians, joggers, and cyclists who are wearing headphones. They may be unable to hear your vehicle approaching and may do dangerous things because they do not know you are there.

questions.question: Blocking is used to:
questions.answerB: Prevent cargo from being loaded too high.
questions.answerC: Prevent cargo from being unloaded too quickly.
questions.explanation: Blocking is used in the front, in the back, and/or on the sides of a piece of cargo to keep it from sliding while the vehicle is in motion.

questions.question: Do not operate a vehicle if any brake drums have cracks that are larger than ____ of the width of the friction area.
questions.explanation: Before beginning a trip, it is important to check the brake drums during your walk-around inspection. It is unsafe to drive if any brake drum has a crack more than one half of the width of the friction area.

questions.question: If you are confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.explanation: If you encounter an aggressive driver, you should not let yourself be provoked by any angry gestures they make toward you. Avoid making eye contact with the other driver and do not try to race them.

questions.question: When accelerating on a surface with poor traction, such as a wet road, a driver should:
questions.answerC: Not be concerned about the pavement.
questions.explanation: You should accelerate very gradually when driving under conditions that create poor traction.

questions.question: After an accident, flares should be used with caution because:
questions.answerA: There may be fuel spilled on the ground that could catch fire.
questions.answerB: Other drivers may not see the flares if the weather is sunny.
questions.explanation: A common cause of vehicle fires in the aftermath of an accident is the improper use of flares near spilled fuel. Use flares with caution.

questions.question: To prevent a vehicle from rolling backward when beginning to move forward from a stopped position, you should:
questions.explanation: To prevent a vehicle with manual transmission from rolling backward when you begin to move forward from a stopped position, you can partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.

questions.question: Too much air pressure in a tire:
questions.explanation: Tires should never have too much air pressure. Be sure to check your tires' air pressure with a gauge during inspections.

questions.question: The Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) does not need to include which of the following?
questions.answerC: Number of meals eaten by the driver
questions.explanation: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include information about the distance traveled by a vehicle and the amount of fuel purchased. The required distance information includes the origin and destination points of the trip and the Vehicle Identification Number.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerB: Tires are not made to drive in wet weather.
questions.answerC: The water yet hasn't absorbed the dirt and grease.
questions.explanation: Roads are often especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Rainwater forms a slick film when mixed with oil and grease on the road surface that has not yet washed away.

questions.question: A distracted driver:
questions.answerA: Usually follows the rules of the road.
questions.answerC: Is a good person to follow.
questions.explanation: Distracted drivers perceive hazards on the road more slowly than drivers who are focused, or they do not perceive hazards at all.

questions.question: Friction in an S-cam brake is caused when the brake shoes and linings:
questions.answerA: Press against the outside of the brake drum.
questions.answerB: Press against the inside of the brake drum.
questions.explanation: Friction inside a brake drum is caused when the brake shoes and linings push against the inside of the drum. The friction in the drums will slow and stop the vehicle.

questions.question: When starting the engine of a truck with a trailer, you can tell that your vehicle's ABS is not working if:
questions.answerA: The yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on.
questions.answerB: The red light on the right side of the trailer flashes three times.
questions.answerC: All the rear lights flash and then turn off.
questions.explanation: When turning on your vehicle's engine, the lights on the dash should come on and then turn off. If the ABS malfunction light stays on, the system is not working properly. In the case of a truck with a trailer, if the yellow light on the left rear of the trailer stays on once the engine has been started, the system is not working properly.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing a truck is always dangerous because the driver may not be able to see everything behind them. CMV operators should avoid backing whenever possible.

questions.question: How much distance will an air brake-equipped vehicle need to come to a complete stop if it is traveling at 55 mph under ideal driving conditions?
questions.explanation: A vehicle's total stopping distance is made up of perception distance, reaction distance, brake lag distance, and braking distance. With all of these factors included, an air brake-equipped vehicle traveling at a speed of 55 mph under ideal driving conditions will need approximately 450 feet to come to a complete stop.

questions.question: If the safety relief valve in an air brake system is releasing air:
questions.answerA: You should not be concerned as this is a normal process.
questions.answerB: There is something wrong with the brakes.
questions.explanation: The safety relief valve in an air brake system releases air if necessary to prevent pressure in the system from becoming too high. If the valve starts releasing air, there is something wrong. Have a mechanic fix the problem.

questions.question: When traveling down a hill, you can reduce the amount of required braking by:
questions.explanation: Before starting down a hill, decelerate and shift down into a gear that will allow you to control your vehicle without braking too hard. Using too much brake when driving downhill can cause the brakes to overheat, reducing the braking power.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system, air pressure should build from 85 to 100 psi within ____ seconds.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a vehicle with a dual air brake system, you should wait for air pressure to build from 85 to 100 psi in both the primary and secondary systems. This should take about 45 seconds.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake must be always be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should never be used.
questions.answerC: Windows in the cab should be lowered.
questions.explanation: Always apply the parking brake when leaving your vehicle unattended.

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: A broken exhaust system:
questions.answerA: Can allow poisonous fumes to enter the cabin.
questions.explanation: A broken exhaust system can let poisonous fumes into a vehicle's cab or sleeper berth. Be sure to inspect your exhaust system for any loose, broken, or missing parts.

questions.question: If a driver has stopped on the road and is placing triangles to warn other motorists:
questions.answerA: The triangles should be held between the driver and oncoming traffic.
questions.answerB: The triangles should be carried behind the driver's back to prevent them from being seen by other drivers until they are placed.
questions.answerC: The triangles should be held as low as possible.
questions.explanation: For your own safety, when placing reflective warning triangles, you should carry them between your body and the oncoming traffic.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, a truck operator should:
questions.answerA: Exchange information with all others involved in the collision.
questions.answerB: Fly a drone to take pictures of the accident scene.
questions.answerC: Immediately drive to the nearest police department to file a report.
questions.explanation: If involved in a collision, you must stop immediately to tend to the injured and exchange information with all others involved. File a report with law enforcement within four days of any collision resulting in injuries or more than $1,000 in damage.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle unattended:
questions.answerA: The parking brake should be used.
questions.answerB: The parking brake only needs to be used if the vehicle is parked on a slope.
questions.answerC: The parking brake should not be used, as it can damage the tires.
questions.explanation: In general, you should always use the parking brake when parking your vehicle. However, you should not apply the parking brake if your brakes are very hot or if your brakes are wet and temperatures are below freezing.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of a driver becoming tired?
questions.explanation: Potential warning signs of fatigued driving include difficulty focusing; frequent blinking or heavy eyelids; yawning repeatedly or rubbing one's eyes; daydreaming; wandering or disconnected thinking; trouble remembering the last few miles driven; missing exits or traffic signs; having trouble keeping one's head up; drifting from one's lane; following a vehicle too closely; hitting a shoulder rumble strip; and feeling restless or irritable.

questions.question: Air pressure should build up in a single air system within:
questions.explanation: In single air systems, air pressure should build from approximately 50 to 90 psi within three minutes.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle controls skills test exercise, your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: In the general area that was described by the examiner.
questions.answerB: In the exact final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Within three feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When making tight maneuvers, it is important for a driver to:
questions.answerA: Open their door for a better look.
questions.explanation: While regular mirror checks should always be part of your driving routine, you should make a particular point of checking the mirrors when changing lanes, turning, merging, or making tight maneuvers.

questions.question: If confronted by an aggressive driver, you should:
questions.answerA: Make eye contact to better communicate with them.
questions.answerC: Not move out of their path of travel.
questions.explanation: If confronted by an aggressive driver, it is most important to get out of their way, if possible. Do not make eye contact with the driver, as doing so could provoke them. Do not let them provoke you with their actions.

questions.question: A poor balance of weight in a trailer:
questions.explanation: Poorly balanced weight in a trailer can make handling unsafe. For example, either too little or too much weight on the front axle can make a vehicle difficult to steer. Weight should be distributed evenly from front to back and from side to side. It should be distributed as low as possible.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerC: The cargo is mostly in the front of the trailer.
questions.explanation: It is essential to the safe operation of a CMV that cargo be properly loaded. Improper loading can affect handling and damage the vehicle. Additionally, improperly loaded materials can cause injury or death by falling off of the vehicle.

questions.question: A stopped bus:
questions.answerA: Is not a cause for concern since it is stopped.
questions.answerB: Is only a concern if passengers are exiting the bus.
questions.answerC: Is a concern whether or not passengers are visible.
questions.explanation: You should always exercise caution when driving near a stopped bus. There could be passengers in the vicinity and the bus may either prevent them from seeing you or you from seeing them.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stand as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stand as far away from the fire as possible. Aim the extinguisher at the base of the fire, not at the flames. If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a cause of hydraulic brake failure?
questions.explanation: Most cases of hydraulic brake failure come from one of two causes. The brakes may fail due to a loss of hydraulic pressure or due to overuse on long hills, causing the brakes to fade.

questions.question: What is the left lane rule?
questions.answerA: Heavy vehicles must only be driven in the left lane of a road with three lanes traveling in one direction.
questions.answerB: Heavy vehicles may only be driven in the left lane of a road with three lanes traveling in one direction if making a left turn.
questions.answerC: Heavy vehicles cannot be driven in the left lane of a three lane road for any purpose.
questions.explanation: Washington State's left lane rule states that no vehicle or combination weighing over 10,000 pounds may be driven in the left lane of a limited-access road with three or more lanes traveling in one direction, unless preparing to make a left turn.

questions.question: A truck tractor built after March 1, 1997 must be equipped with:
questions.explanation: Truck tractors with air brakes built on or after March 1, 1997 are required to be equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS).

questions.question: You should ____ if the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving.
questions.answerA: Stop where you are and park
questions.answerB: Exit the roadway as soon as safely possible
questions.explanation: If the low pressure warning signal activates while you are driving, it is important that you safely exit the roadway as soon as possible and park your vehicle. If the air pressure gets too low, the brakes will no longer work well enough for you to stop safely.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a sign of fatigue?
questions.explanation: Potential warning signs of fatigue include difficulty focusing, frequent blinking, or heavy eyelids; yawning repeatedly or rubbing your eyes; daydreaming; wandering or disconnected thoughts; trouble remembering the last few miles you've driven; missing exits or traffic signs; having trouble keeping your head up; drifting from your lane; following too closely; hitting a shoulder rumble strip; or feeling restless and irritable.

questions.question: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) does not need to include which of the following?
questions.explanation: An Individual Vehicle Distance Record (IVDR) must include information about the distance traveled by a vehicle and the amount of fuel purchased. The required distance information includes the dates of a trip and the total distance traveled by the vehicle.
