questions.question: If an unusual noise or feeling occurs in a vehicle while it is being driven, the driver should:
questions.answerA: Assume it is not a concern and continue driving.
questions.answerB: Hope the vehicle does alright until it is switched to another driver.
questions.answerC: Check the situation to determine the proper solution.
questions.explanation: If you see, hear, smell, or feel anything while driving that does not feel right, you should have it checked out.

questions.question: When taking the basic vehicle control skills test, failing to exit your vehicle properly during any exercise will result in:
questions.answerB: An extra point against your final score.
questions.answerC: Automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Talk to students on the bus.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should always approach bus stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: If a school bus stalls on a railroad track:
questions.answerA: Students should remain on the bus.
questions.answerB: Students should be evacuated to a location near the bus.
questions.answerC: Students should be evacuated and moved away from the bus.
questions.explanation: If a school bus becomes stalled or trapped on railroad tracks, the driver should immediately evacuate everyone from the bus. If the bus is struck by a train, to avoid any flying debris, the students should be led far away from the bus at an angle that is in the direction of any oncoming train.

questions.question: If taking the driving test and the route does not include a railroad crossing, you:
questions.answerA: Will not have to do anything related to a crossing.
questions.answerB: May have to explain how you would cross railroad tracks.
questions.answerC: Will have to take the test again on a route that does include a railroad crossing.
questions.explanation: If your on-road driving test route does not include a railroad crossing, you may be asked to explain and demonstrate the proper railroad crossing procedures to the examiner at a simulated location.

questions.question: If there is a fire on a school bus, the students:
questions.answerB: Should stay on the bus but be moved to a part of the bus unaffected by the fire.
questions.explanation: If a school bus is on fire, or if there is a threat of fire, it is mandatory for a bus driver to evacuate the students from the bus.

questions.question: ABS helps you:
questions.answerB: Keep your wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: Count the number of students boarding the bus.
questions.explanation: The function of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to prevent a vehicle's wheels from locking up when the driver brakes hard on a slippery surface.

questions.question: A post-trip inspection should include all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Looking for articles left on the bus.
questions.explanation: After completing a trip, a school bus driver should do an inspection in which they check for sleeping students; belongings left on the bus; open windows or doors; any mechanical or operational issues with the bus; and damage or vandalism.

questions.question: Properly adjusted crossover mirrors allow you to see all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: The right and left front tires touching the ground.
questions.answerB: The area in front of the bus.
questions.answerC: The tops of the right and left rear tires.
questions.explanation: Properly adjusted crossover mirrors on a school bus should allow the driver to see the entire area in front of the bus, from the front bumper at ground level to a point where direct vision is possible. The mirrors should also display the right and left front tires touching the ground, as well as the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure there is a gap between the kingpin and the locking jaws.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a tractor/trailer coupling, look into the fifth wheel gap and make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.

questions.question: Backing a school bus is:
questions.answerC: Only to be done in the morning.
questions.explanation: Backing a school bus is strongly discouraged and should only be done if there is no safe alternative. If you must drive in reverse, be sure to follow all proper safety protocol.

questions.question: If a tornado is approaching and there is no nearby shelter, where should students go?
questions.explanation: If students are evacuated due to a school bus being in the direct path of a sighted tornado, the driver should lead them to shelter in a nearby building. If no such shelter is available, the driver should escort them to a nearby ditch or culvert. They should avoid areas that may be subject to flash flooding and should be far enough away from the bus that it would not fall on them if it tipped over.

questions.question: If your bus is equipped with a roof-mounted strobe light, it should be used:
questions.explanation: If equipped, a school bus's roof-mounted strobe light should be used when conditions create an environment of limited visibility.

questions.question: The inside rearview mirror is used to:
questions.answerB: See potential hazards on the road.
questions.answerC: See vehicles trying to switch lanes.
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror in a school bus is used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: Loading and unloading a bus:
questions.answerB: Does not need to be supervised.
questions.explanation: More students are killed each year during loading or unloading of school buses than while riding on school buses. Therefore, it is critical that school bus drivers follow appropriate safety procedures during loading and unloading.

questions.question: When completing a driver's side parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.answerB: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the left of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: With the exception of the straight line backing exercise, a driver may exit their vehicle and check its position during testing exercises up to:
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic vehicle control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: After students unload at the school, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Not be concerned with the students' whereabouts.
questions.answerB: Leave after the students have entered the school building.
questions.answerC: Walk through the bus to check for any sleeping students.
questions.explanation: After students unload at school, a school bus driver should walk through the bus to check for sleeping students, hiding students, and items that students may have left behind. Students should exit the bus in an orderly fashion with the driver supervising.

questions.question: When boarding a school bus, students should:
questions.explanation: Students should board a school bus slowly and in a single-file line. For safety, boarding students should use the handrail.

questions.question: If a student drops an item while approaching a school bus, the student should:
questions.answerA: Stop and pick up the object.
questions.answerB: Have another student pick up the object.
questions.answerC: Ask the driver to pick up the object.
questions.explanation: If a student tries to retrieve a dropped object, they may disappear from the driver's line of sight. This is potentially very dangerous. Rather than retrieve dropped items themselves, students should move to a point of safety outside of the bus's danger zones, get the driver's attention, and wait for the driver to retrieve what has been dropped.

questions.question: During the driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on:
questions.answerB: How quickly you arrive to your destination.
questions.explanation: During the on-road driving test, the examiner will be scoring you on specific driving maneuvers, as well as your general driving behavior.

questions.question: Where is the overhead inside rearview mirror located?
questions.answerA: Above the windshield on the driverâ€™s side of the bus
questions.answerB: Above the door across from the driver
questions.answerC: Above the emergency door in the rear
questions.explanation: The overhead inside rearview mirror of a school bus should be mounted directly above the windshield on the driverâ€™s side of the vehicle. It should be used to monitor passenger activity inside the bus.

questions.question: Crossover mirrors help the driver see:
questions.answerC: The left side of the bus.
questions.explanation: Crossover mirrors are used to help a driver see the danger zone area directly in front of a school bus. The mirrors should also display the danger zone areas to the left and right sides of the bus, including the area from the front of the bus to the service door.

questions.question: When stopping to pick up students, be sure to park at least 10 feet away from the students because:
questions.answerA: You will have a good view of their movements.
questions.answerB: It will be difficult to get any closer to the students.
questions.explanation: When picking up passengers, a school bus driver should park with the vehicle's front bumper at least 10 feet away from the students. This is the safest parking option because it forces the students to walk to the bus, making it possible for the driver to watch their movements.

questions.question: ABS allows a driver to:
questions.answerB: Maintain control of their vehicle while braking.
questions.answerC: See farther ahead of their vehicle.
questions.explanation: The purpose of an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is to help prevent wheel lockup and help a driver maintain control of their vehicle when braking on a slippery surface.

questions.question: Backing a school bus is:
questions.answerC: Only to be done in the morning.
questions.explanation: Backing a school bus is strongly discouraged and should only be done if there is no safe alternative. If you must drive in reverse, be sure to follow all proper safety protocol.

questions.question: During a basic vehicle controls skills test exercise, your vehicle's final position should be:
questions.answerA: In the general area that was described by the examiner.
questions.answerB: In the exact final position described by the examiner.
questions.answerC: Within three feet of the final position described by the examiner.
questions.explanation: You should finish each exercise with your vehicle in the exact position described by the examiner. You can be penalized for failing to complete an exercise exactly in the manner described by the examiner, potentially resulting in failure of the basic control skills test.

questions.question: When approaching a school bus stop, the driver should:
questions.answerC: Talk to students on the bus.
questions.explanation: A school bus driver should always approach bus stops slowly and cautiously.

questions.question: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, you should:
questions.answerA: Prepare to proceed as soon as a train passes.
questions.answerC: Open the door to listen for approaching trains.
questions.explanation: When stopped at a railroad crossing while operating a school bus, do not rely only on signals to tell you if a train is approaching. You should silence all passengers, open the front door, and look and listen for trains. After a train has passed, you should check for another train approaching from either direction before you proceed across the tracks.

questions.question: If your vehicle's ABS is malfunctioning:
questions.answerA: You will not have any working brakes.
questions.answerC: You should only use the parking brake.
questions.explanation: Anti-lock brakes are meant to keep a vehicle's wheels from locking up during hard applications. If your vehicle's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) malfunctions, its standard braking functions should still be in place. You should continue to drive and brake in a normal manner.

questions.question: School buses:
questions.answerB: Are only equipped with ABS if students who are younger than 10 years of age will be on the bus.
questions.explanation: In general, school buses manufactured after 1998 or 1999 must be equipped with an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS). Many older buses are equipped with ABS as well.

questions.question: If a gate controlling a railroad crossing does not go back up after a train passes, you should:
questions.answerB: Wait for another vehicle to cross the tracks first to see if it is safe.
questions.explanation: If you are stopped at a railroad crossing and a gate fails to return to its open position after a train passes, call your dispatcher. Do not attempt to drive around the lowered gate.

questions.question: Doors should be closed while a school bus is being driven, except when:
questions.answerB: Needing to cool off the inside of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: There is no vehicle next to the bus.
questions.explanation: The doors of a school bus must be kept closed any time the bus is moving, except when it is crossing railroad tracks.

questions.question: As a general rule, where should students be kept during an emergency?
questions.answerB: On the side of the road near the bus
questions.answerC: In a field away from the bus
questions.explanation: In most emergency or crisis situations, students on a school bus will be safer and more easily controlled if they are kept on the bus than if they are evacuated. However, if staying on a bus will expose the students to risk or injury, the bus driver should escort them to a safe location.

questions.question: At a passive railroad crossing, the decision to proceed:
questions.answerB: Is indicated by a control device.
questions.answerC: Is decided by the vehicle in front of you.
questions.explanation: Railroad crossings that do not have any kind of traffic control device are known as passive crossings. The decision to proceed across tracks at a passive crossing is entirely up to the driver.

questions.question: If exiting a bus, a driver must:
questions.answerA: Never make contact with the handrail.
questions.explanation: When exiting your vehicle during the basic vehicle control skills test, you must face the vehicle and maintain three points of contact at all times. If your testing vehicle is a bus, you must maintain contact with the handrail. Exiting the vehicle incorrectly may result in automatic failure of the basic vehicle control skills test.

questions.question: When completing a conventional parallel parking maneuver, you should:
questions.answerA: Back up past the parking space, then pull forward into it.
questions.answerB: Pull forward past the parking space, then back into it.
questions.answerC: Pull forward directly into the parking space.
questions.explanation: You may be asked to complete a conventional parallel parking maneuver into a parking space that is to the right of your vehicle. You should drive past the parking space before backing into it while bringing the rear of your vehicle as close to the rear of the space as possible. Your vehicle should be completely within the boundaries of the space.

questions.question: Before a trip, you should make sure that:
questions.answerC: The grooved pedal surface has not been smoothed out.
questions.explanation: When checking your vehicle's pedals during a pre-trip inspection, you should ensure that there is nothing under or around the pedals that will obstruct their use. Make sure the pedals are in proper working condition and that the surfaces of the pedals are grooved, if applicable.

questions.question: When dropping off students at a school, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Secure the bus by turning off the engine.
questions.answerB: Leave the key in the ignition, if leaving the driverâ€™s compartment.
questions.answerC: Read a book while students unload.
questions.explanation: When unloading students at a school, a bus driver must secure the bus by turning off the engine. If they must leave the driver's compartment, they should remove the key from the ignition. The driver must supervise the unloading process.

questions.question: With the exception of the straight line backing exercise, a driver may exit their vehicle and check its position during testing exercises up to:
questions.explanation: A driver is allowed to exit their vehicle to check its position during any basic vehicle control skills test exercise. This action is called a "look." During the straight line backing exercise, a driver may not exceed one look. During any other exercise, a driver may not exceed two looks.

questions.question: When trying to control a minor truck fire, what should you do before opening trailer doors?
questions.answerA: Check to see if the doors are hot.
questions.explanation: If you are experiencing a truck fire, you should not attempt to open trailer doors without first feeling the doors to see if they are hot. If the doors are hot, there may be a cargo fire. Leave the doors closed if there is a cargo fire.

questions.question: Placards showing the type of hazardous materials in a vehicle are usually which shape?
questions.explanation: In general, vehicles carrying hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs on all four sides. These warning signs are called "placards."

questions.question: When Division 1.3 materials are being transported, the floor liner should be:
questions.explanation: You should use a floor lining when transporting Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 materials. The floors must be tight and the liner must be made from either non-metallic material or non-ferrous metal. Non-ferrous metals are any metals that do not contain iron or iron alloys.

questions.question: A materialâ€™s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination.
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: If you notice a cargo leak, you should identify the leaking hazardous materials by:
questions.explanation: If you discover a cargo leak while transporting hazardous materials, use the shipping papers, label, or package location to identify which materials are involved. Do not try to touch or smell the leaking materials to determine what they are because doing so could result in injury or death.

questions.question: Many products classed as poison are also:
questions.explanation: Many hazardous materials classified as poisonous are also flammable.

questions.question: A hazardous material's identification number should appear:
questions.answerC: On a sticker near the material's shipping container.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It also must appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: If transporting chlorine, what must be in the vehicle?
questions.explanation: If transporting chlorine in cargo tanks, a driver must have an approved gas mask in their vehicle.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Always load hazardous materials away from heat sources. Be aware of regulations on explosive or flammable materials that prohibit them from being loaded in cargo spaces with heaters.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: If loading corrosive materials, you should not:
questions.explanation: If loading by hand, load breakable containers of corrosive liquid one by one. Keep them facing upright. Do not drop or roll the containers.

questions.question: During a cargo fire, opening the trailer doors may actually cause the fire to expand because doing so:
questions.answerB: Changes the temperature of the trailer.
questions.answerC: Provides more moisture to the trailer.
questions.explanation: When experiencing a cargo fire, it may be a bad idea to open the doors to the trailer. Doing so allows oxygen to enter the area, potentially causing the fire to flare up and expand.

questions.question: If a package contains liquid containers, the box must display:
questions.answerA: Arrows pointing in the correct upright direction.
questions.answerC: The number of containers inside the box.
questions.explanation: Packages that contain liquid containers must have orientation markers. Arrows displayed on the box should be pointing in the correct upright direction.

questions.question: How often are hazardous materials employees required to be trained and tested?
questions.explanation: All drivers must be trained in the security risks of hazardous materials transportation. This training must include how to recognize and respond to possible security threats. Hazardous materials employees must be trained and tested at least once every three years.

questions.question: If a driver is given a leaking package or shipment, they should:
questions.answerC: Leave it on the side of the road.
questions.explanation: It is a driver's responsibility to refuse packages or shipments of hazardous materials if they contain leaks.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may need to be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or properly marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: If your engine runs a pump used during delivery of compressed gas, you should turn off the engine:
questions.explanation: Unless your engine runs a pump for product transfer, turn it off when loading or unloading a compressed gas tank. If you do use your engine to run a pump, you should turn the engine off after the product transfer but before unhooking the hoses.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are usually shaped like:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are usually diamond-shaped.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation surrounds the package and will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be transported in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply the warning placards.

questions.question: To know which placard to use, you need to know:
questions.answerA: The hazard class of the materials.
questions.answerB: The type of container that is holding the materials.
questions.explanation: To determine which placards need to be used, you must know the hazard class of the materials being shipped, the amount of hazardous materials being shipped, and the total weight of all hazardous materials in your vehicle.

questions.question: A placard indicating hazardous materials is shaped like a:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are diamond-shaped.

questions.question: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must carry a fire extinguisher with a minimum rating of:
questions.explanation: The power unit of a placarded vehicle must be equipped with a fire extinguisher with an Underwriters Laboratories (UL) rating of 10 B:C or more.

questions.question: Containers of hazardous materials must be:
questions.answerB: Braced to prevent movement during transportation.
questions.explanation: Containers of hazardous materials should be braced so they will not fall, slide, or bounce around during transportation.

questions.question: If "Inhalation Hazard" appears on a shipping paper, the shipper should provide which placard?
questions.answerB: Poison Gas or Poison Inhalation Hazard
questions.explanation: If the words "Inhalation Hazard" appear on the shipping paper or package, you must display the "Poison Inhalation Hazard" or "Poison Gas" placards, as appropriate.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in the business of firework or munition dealing.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that involves such materials. Examples include paint dealers; chemical suppliers; scientific supply houses; pest control businesses; agricultural supply firms; and dealers in explosives, munitions, or fireworks.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building, unless you are parking for a short period of time while performing an operational necessity, like refueling.

questions.question: If you're transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you should notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down while you are transporting explosives and you need to use warning signals, use reflective triangles or red electric lights. Never use burning signals, such as flares or fuses, when transporting explosives.

questions.question: When loading compressed gas, the liquid discharge valves should be:
questions.explanation: On a compressed gas tank, liquid discharge valves must always be kept closed, except during loading and unloading.

questions.question: In addition to reading the manual, the best way to learn about transporting hazardous materials is to:
questions.explanation: While the manual includes all of the information required to pass the hazardous materials knowledge test, you should consider reading the manual as only the first step to learning about the topic. You can learn more by reading and understanding the federal and state rules about the transportation of hazardous materials, as well as by attending hazardous materials training courses.

questions.question: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a background check through which agency?
questions.explanation: When applying for an original or renewed HazMat endorsement, you must undergo a federal security threat assessment done by the Transportation Security Administration (TSA).

questions.question: While driving, shipping papers should be:
questions.explanation: While hazardous materials are being transported, shipping papers should either be kept in a pouch in the driver's side door or in another location where the driver is able to easily reach them while their seat belt is fastened. The papers must be clearly visible to anyone who is entering the cab.

questions.question: Shipping papers must include:
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to include an emergency response telephone number on shipping papers.

questions.question: A hazardous material's identification number should appear:
questions.answerC: On a sticker near the material's shipping container.
questions.explanation: A material's ID number must appear on its accompanying shipping paper as well as on its packaging. It also must appear on cargo tanks and other bulk packaging.

questions.question: A materialâ€™s hazard class reflects:
questions.answerA: The risks associated with the material.
questions.answerB: How quickly the material must reach its destination.
questions.explanation: A hazardous material will be placed into one of nine classes to explain the type of risks associated with the material.

questions.question: Which type of material may be required to have a transport index?
questions.explanation: Some radioactive materials are required to be accompanied by a transport index. A transport index is a number that indicates how much control the material will require during transport. The total transport index of all cargo in a single vehicle may not exceed 50.

questions.question: If a driver stops and leaves their vehicle while transporting hazardous materials, the shipping papers should be:
questions.answerB: Left in the front seat of the cab.
questions.answerC: Placed in a box under the passenger seat.
questions.explanation: If a driver stops and exits their vehicle, the hazardous materials shipping papers must be left on the driver's seat.

questions.question: If transporting hazardous materials, a shipper should warn others by:
questions.answerA: Posting HazMat placards on their truck.
questions.answerB: Putting flashing lights on their truck.
questions.explanation: Shippers of certain kinds of hazardous materials are required to display diamond-shaped warning signs, known as placards, on any transporting vehicles. Shippers are required to provide applicable placards, labels, shipping papers, and emergency response information.

questions.question: Who must mark and label the materials for shipping?
questions.explanation: Shippers of hazardous materials are required to warn drivers and others about the risks of the materials by putting hazard warning labels on packages, putting placards on the transporting vehicles, and providing proper shipping papers and emergency response information.

questions.question: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be:
questions.answerA: Inside a gas station looking through a window.
questions.answerB: In the vehicle, awake or asleep.
questions.explanation: A person attending a placarded vehicle must be awake inside the vehicle or otherwise within 100 feet of the vehicle; know the hazards associated with the materials; know what to do in an emergency; and be able and authorized to move the tank if necessary.

questions.question: If you identify hazardous materials leaking while you are driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Continue driving to find a phone booth and call the National Response Center.
questions.answerC: Leave the area to find help.
questions.explanation: If you discover that a cargo of hazardous materials is leaking from your vehicle, you should park the vehicle as soon as possible. The longer you continue driving, the longer the trail of contamination becomes. While this creates potential danger and harm to others, it also increases clean-up expenses.

questions.question: If you're transporting explosives and your vehicle breaks down, you should notify other drivers:
questions.answerC: By standing on the roadway and waving your arms.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle breaks down while you are transporting explosives and you need to use warning signals, use reflective triangles or red electric lights. Never use burning signals, such as flares or fuses, when transporting explosives.

questions.question: A placard should be placed:
questions.answerA: At least three inches away from any other markings.
questions.answerB: Under a ladder, if space is an issue.
questions.answerC: On a background that is a similar color to the placard.
questions.explanation: A placard must be placed at least three inches away from any other markings. The placard should be kept clear of attachments or devices, such as doors and ladders. Placards should always be placed against a background of a contrasting color.

questions.question: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials may need to be:
questions.answerB: Circled by a pen or marker.
questions.explanation: If a shipping paper describes both hazardous and non-hazardous materials, the hazardous materials must be distinguished in one of three ways. They must be entered first on the shipping paper, highlighted in a contrasting color, or properly marked with an "X" in a column titled "HM."

questions.question: ____ are used to warn others of hazardous materials.
questions.explanation: Diamond-shaped signs called placards are placed on bulk packages and on the outside of vehicles to warn drivers and others of the presence of hazardous materials. It is the responsibility of the shipper to place the placards, and it is the responsibility of the driver to verify that the correct placards have been placed.

questions.question: If you are transporting hazardous materials and the cargo is on fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Try to put it out with a fire extinguisher.
questions.answerB: Contact emergency personnel and let them battle the fire.
questions.answerC: Hope the fire goes out by itself.
questions.explanation: Fighting a hazardous materials fire requires special training and protective gear. Unless you have the proper equipment and training, do not try to fight a hazardous materials fire yourself.

questions.question: A driver should ensure that:
questions.answerA: The shipping paper matches the markings and labels on packages.
questions.answerB: The shipping paper is written in code.
questions.answerC: All packages are labeled as poison.
questions.explanation: It is always a good idea to compare package markings and labels to accompanying shipping papers. Always make sure the shipper has displayed the correct basic description on the shipping paper and has provided the proper labels on the packages.

questions.question: When refueling a vehicle carrying hazardous materials:
questions.answerA: The engine should be left on.
questions.answerB: The engine should be turned off.
questions.answerC: The gas nozzle may be left unattended.
questions.explanation: If you need to refuel a vehicle carrying hazardous materials, you must first turn off the engine. While refueling, someone must be at the nozzle and controlling the fuel flow at all times.

questions.question: Hazardous materials placards are usually shaped like:
questions.explanation: Hazardous materials warning placards are usually diamond-shaped.

questions.question: If transporting a package that contains radioactive materials, it is important to know that:
questions.answerA: Radiation surrounds the package and will pass through to other packages.
questions.answerB: The package should be transported in the cab.
questions.answerC: The package should be loaded on their side.
questions.explanation: Radiation will surround each package of radioactive materials and pass through to all nearby packages. The number of packages that can be loaded together is controlled.

questions.question: The only way to effectively check your tire pressure is:
questions.answerC: By pushing on the tire to feel the pressure.
questions.explanation: You must examine each tire on a motor vehicle at the beginning of each trip. The only effective way to check tire pressure is by using a tire pressure gauge.

questions.question: Hazardous materials shipping papers may not be kept:
questions.answerA: In a pouch on the driverâ€™s door.
questions.answerB: In a pouch on the passengerâ€™s side door.
questions.answerC: Within reach of the driver while the seat belt is fastened.
questions.explanation: Shipping papers must be quickly accessible in the event of an emergency. While driving, operators must keep the papers in a pouch on the driverâ€™s door or in clear view and within immediate reach while their seat belt is fastened. Shipping papers may be kept on the driverâ€™s seat when the driver is out of the vehicle.

questions.question: A clue that your shipment contains hazardous materials is that:
questions.answerA: The shipper is in the business of firework or munition dealing.
questions.answerB: The last shipment you picked up was labeled as hazardous.
questions.explanation: One clue that a shipment may contain hazardous materials is that the shipper is in a line of business that involves such materials. Examples include paint dealers; chemical suppliers; scientific supply houses; pest control businesses; agricultural supply firms; and dealers in explosives, munitions, or fireworks.

questions.question: If you discover that your cargo is leaking, you should:
questions.answerA: Touch the leaking material to identify the cargo.
questions.answerB: Use shipping papers and labels to identify the leaking cargo.
questions.answerC: Assume all the cargo is leaking.
questions.explanation: If you discover a leak in a cargo of hazardous materials, identify the materials in question by using the shipping papers, labels, or package location. Do not touch the leaking material.

questions.question: If loading corrosive materials, you should not:
questions.explanation: If loading by hand, load breakable containers of corrosive liquid one by one. Keep them facing upright. Do not drop or roll the containers.

questions.question: Who must label hazardous materials?
questions.explanation: The shipper of hazardous materials is responsible for packaging, marking, and labeling the materials. They must supply the warning placards.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Always load hazardous materials away from heat sources. Be aware of regulations on explosive or flammable materials that prohibit them from being loaded in cargo spaces with heaters.

questions.question: To transport hazardous materials, a driver needs:
questions.answerB: A CDL with hazardous materials endorsement.
questions.answerC: A CDL with a tank endorsement.
questions.explanation: To drive a vehicle of any size that is used to transport hazardous materials, you must have a CDL with a hazardous materials endorsement.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing while transporting chlorine:
questions.answerA: You must stop before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerB: You must reduce your speed before crossing the tracks.
questions.answerC: You may proceed across the tracks without stopping if no warning lights are flashing.
questions.explanation: If transporting any amount of chlorine, a driver must always stop at a railroad crossing 15 to 50 feet from the nearest track, regardless of the presence of a train.

questions.question: When traveling with Division 1.1 explosives, you may park no closer than ____ from the nearest building.
questions.explanation: When carrying Division 1.1, 1.2, or 1.3 explosives, you should not park within 300 feet of a bridge, tunnel, or building, unless you are parking for a short period of time while performing an operational necessity, like refueling.

questions.question: If an air compressor is belt-driven, the belt should be routinely checked to ensure that it is:
questions.explanation: If your vehicle has air brakes, the air compressor drive belt should be checked before each drive. Check the tightness of the belt and verify that it is in good condition.

questions.question: Keeping cargo low can:
questions.explanation: Rollovers can happen when a combination vehicle is turned too quickly. To help prevent the risk of rollover, it is important to keep the vehicle's center of gravity low by loading cargo as close to the ground as possible.

questions.question: When driving on a long downhill slope, you should brake by:
questions.answerB: Mostly using the brakes and occasionally downshifting.
questions.answerC: Downshifting and then using the brakes.
questions.explanation: When approaching a long downgrade, you should shift into a lower gear then use proper braking techniques. Using the brakes alone could cause them to overheat and fail. The braking power of the engine, which is maximized by being in a lower gear, will be the principal way of controlling your speed on a downgrade.

questions.question: To avoid a collision with a hazard on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You should always try to stop.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be a safer option than stopping.
questions.explanation: Swerving out of the way of a hazard is sometimes safer than trying to stop before reaching the hazard. You can usually turn away from something more quickly than you can come to a complete stop.

questions.question: Skids caused by over-acceleration can usually be resolved by:
questions.answerA: Removing your foot from the accelerator.
questions.explanation: A skid caused by over-acceleration can be resolved simply by removing your foot from the accelerator. Skids of this nature happen most frequently on surfaces covered in snow or ice.

questions.question: As part of the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerA: Explain why you must check the items you are checking.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: If feeling drowsy while driving, you should:
questions.answerA: Press on and finish the trip.
questions.answerB: Drive faster to reach your destination more quickly.
questions.answerC: Safely leave the road and take a nap.
questions.explanation: If you begin to feel drowsy while driving, the best thing to do is to stop and get some sleep. A driver trying to push on and finish a trip while fatigued is a major cause of fatal accidents.

questions.question: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to:
questions.answerB: Explain to the examiner what you are inspecting and why.
questions.answerC: Estimate the weight of a load on a trailer.
questions.explanation: During the vehicle inspection test, you will be asked to do a complete inspection of your vehicle. You will need to explain what you are inspecting and why.

questions.question: During an inspection, slack adjusters on S-cam brakes should not move more than:
questions.explanation: Check each slack adjuster after parking on level ground, setting wheel chocks, and disengaging the parking brake. Pull the slack adjusters to make sure they do not move more than about one inch from where the push rod is attached. If they move more than one inch, they may be out of adjustment and will need to be fixed.

questions.question: A trailer that is not at the proper height:
questions.explanation: Before coupling together a tractor and a trailer, you should make sure the trailer is at the proper height. If the trailer is too low, the trailer nose may be damaged. If the trailer is too high, it may not be able to couple correctly.

questions.question: When checking power steering hoses during a pre-trip inspection, you should look for:
questions.answerC: Extra hose pieces available for repairs.
questions.explanation: When doing a pre-trip inspection on a vehicle with power steering, be sure to check the hoses, pumps, and fluid level. In particular, you should check the hoses for leaks.

questions.question: A cardboard box on the roadway:
questions.answerA: Should be expected to be on the roadway.
questions.answerC: Could contain a heavy object that could damage vehicles.
questions.explanation: Almost any foreign object on the road poses some potential danger. For example, even something as seemingly harmless as a cardboard box could contain a hard or heavy object that could damage your vehicle.

questions.question: Watching the road ahead:
questions.answerA: Is more dangerous than only watching your mirrors.
questions.answerB: Does not help you drive more safely.
questions.answerC: Can help you avoid the need for sudden lane changes.
questions.explanation: Making a sudden lane change can be dangerous while driving a combination vehicle. You can avoid the need to make a sudden lange change by looking down the road for upcoming obstacles that will require you to change lanes.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a good rule when using turn signals?
questions.answerA: Signal early. Signal well before a turn or lane change.
questions.answerB: Signal continuously. Do not cancel a signal until the turn is completed.
questions.answerC: Donâ€™t over-signal. If no one is near you, there is no need to signal.
questions.explanation: When using your turn signals, you should signal well before the turn or lane change, signal continuously throughout the turn or lane change, and cancel the signal after you have completed your move.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: When are people usually the least alert?
questions.explanation: Most drivers are the least alert at night, especially after midnight. Therefore, crashes due to fatigued driving are more likely at night than any other time of day.

questions.question: When should you slow for a curve?
questions.explanation: You should always slow to a safe speed before entering a curve. Slowing while within the curve could cause a skid.

questions.question: When parking, you should:
questions.answerA: Share a parking lot with automobiles.
questions.answerB: Park in a way that will prevent you from having to back up.
questions.answerC: Ask drivers of smaller vehicles to move.
questions.explanation: Backing is always dangerous and should be avoided whenever possible. When parking, you should seek a space that allows you to pull forward when exiting. Try not to park near smaller vehicles to help you avoid maneuvering issues.

questions.question: What should happen before the air pressure in an air brake system tank falls below 55 psi?
questions.answerB: The vehicle will be unable to shift out of gear.
questions.explanation: The low air pressure warning signal must activate before the air supply pressure drops below 55 psi in the air tank. If the warning signal does not turn on when being tested during an inspection, the vehicle is not safe to drive.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve (also referred to as the "trolley valve" or "Johnson bar") works the trailer brakes and should be used only when testing them. Using the trailer hand valve while driving could result in a skid.

questions.question: Bobtail tractors are ____ to stop than tractors attached to full semitrailers.
questions.explanation: Bobtail tractors are tractors that are not attached to any semitrailers. When operating a bobtail, you should be aware that stopping can be difficult and that it will take a longer distance to come to a complete stop than a tractor attached to a loaded semitrailer.

questions.question: What is road rage?
questions.answerA: Operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others
questions.answerB: Operating a motor vehicle that is deemed unsafe
questions.answerC: Operating a motor vehicle that has not been inspected
questions.explanation: Aggressive driving is defined as operating a motor vehicle in a selfish, bold, or pushy manner. Road rage is defined as operating a motor vehicle with the intent of doing harm to others, or the intent of physically assaulting another driver or their vehicle.

questions.question: When should you slow for a curve?
questions.explanation: You should always slow to a safe speed before entering a curve. Slowing while within the curve could cause a skid.

questions.question: When starting your vehicle, the coolant temperature should:
questions.answerC: Quickly jump from low to high.
questions.explanation: Watch the gauges in your vehicle before starting a trip. After starting your vehicle's engine, the coolant temperature should begin a gradual rise to the normal operating range.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a front tire.
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: When making a left turn, you should start the turn:
questions.answerA: Before reaching the center of the intersection.
questions.answerB: No sooner than the center of the intersection.
questions.answerC: After your rear wheels have passed the center of the intersection.
questions.explanation: When making a left turn, you should wait until you reach the center of the intersection before actually beginning to turn. Due to off-tracking, the left side of your vehicle could hit another driver if you begin turning too early.

questions.question: To change lanes, you should:
questions.explanation: Always change lanes slowly and smoothly. If you did not see drivers who are already using the lane you wish to occupy, this will give them a chance to get out of your way or honk their horns to alert you. Always signal when changing lanes.

questions.question: When parked on a flat surface, you should:
questions.answerA: Use wheel chocks to prevent your vehicle from moving.
questions.answerC: Use wheel chocks, but only if you have applied the parking brake.
questions.explanation: When parking on a level surface, you should use wheel chocks. If the vehicle is not equipped with spring brakes, this is essential to prevent the trailer from moving.

questions.question: When driving, it is important that you:
questions.answerA: Develop plans to get out of potentially dangerous situations.
questions.answerC: Turn your head all the way around rather than use mirrors.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should continually scan the road for possible hazards. Form plans about what you will do if the hazards develop into emergencies.

questions.question: Lights that indicate that anti-lock brakes are not working are:
questions.explanation: Vehicles equipped with Anti-Lock Braking Systems (ABS) have yellow malfunction lights to indicate issues in the braking system.

questions.question: On flat surfaces, wheel chocks:
questions.answerA: Can be used to prevent a parked vehicle from moving.
questions.answerB: Make it easier for a parked vehicle to roll.
questions.answerC: Should only be used on the front driver's side tire.
questions.explanation: In situations where a driver cannot use a parking brake, wheel chocks can be used to hold a parked vehicle in place on a level surface.

questions.question: In a dual air brake system:
questions.answerA: Air tanks are shared between both systems.
questions.answerB: Each system has its own air tanks.
questions.answerC: You must designate which system you are using.
questions.explanation: There are two air brake systems in a dual air brake system. The systems share a set of brake controls, but each system has its own tanks, hoses, and lines.

questions.question: Pre-trip inspections are:
questions.answerB: Needed only for trips longer than 100 miles in length.
questions.explanation: Federal and state laws require drivers to inspect their vehicles before every trip, regardless of length.

questions.question: What kind of brakes do most newer heavy-duty trucks use?
questions.explanation: Most newer heavy-duty vehicles use dual air brake systems. A dual air brake system has two separate air brake systems which use a single set of brake controls.

questions.question: When trying to put out an electrical fire, you should:
questions.explanation: B:C fire extinguishers are designed to work on electrical fires and burning liquids. Don't pour water on an electrical fire.

questions.question: Of the following, which is not a recommended way to spot potential signs of trouble?
questions.answerC: Checking critical items only at the beginning and end of a trip
questions.explanation: During a trip, you should regularly make checks to ensure that your vehicle is operating properly. Check the instrument panel and gauges; look at your mirrors; and examine the tires, cargo, and lights. Use all of your senses and be alert for anything that could be an early indication of trouble.

questions.question: If you cannot reverse your trailer in a straight path, you should:
questions.answerA: Swerve back and forth while backing.
questions.explanation: If you need to back your trailer but cannot back up in a straight path, you should back on a curved path toward the driver's side of the vehicle. This will allow you the best possible visibility while backing.

questions.question: Brakes out of adjustment will:
questions.answerB: Cause some of the brakes to overwork and malfunction.
questions.explanation: Brakes out of adjustment will fade before those that are properly adjusted. Brake adjustment must be checked frequently to help prevent brake issues.

questions.question: The "crack-the-whip" effect is caused by:
questions.explanation: Vehicles with trailers are vulnerable to rollover due to the "crack-the-whip" effect, which is caused by rearward amplification. Rearward amplification varies from vehicle to vehicle, so it is important that drivers are aware of the rearward amplification of their specific vehicles.

questions.question: Before a trip, ensure that the fifth wheel is:
questions.explanation: When inspecting the convertor dolly, make sure all components are present and in proper working condition. Be sure to check the upper and lower fifth wheel, the air lines, and the electric lines. The fifth wheel should be properly greased and securely mounted.

questions.question: The trailer hand valve should be used:
questions.answerB: To check the connection between the trailer and tractor.
questions.explanation: The trailer hand valve (also referred to as the "trolley valve" or "Johnson bar") works the trailer brakes and should be used only when testing them. Using the trailer hand valve while driving could result in a skid.

questions.question: If driving on a surface with poor traction, a driver should accelerate slowly:
questions.answerA: Because it is always good to accelerate slowly.
questions.answerB: To keep from losing control of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: So that they do not accelerate faster than the vehicle ahead.
questions.explanation: To avoid a loss of control, you should accelerate slowly when driving in poor-traction conditions, such as rain or snow.

questions.question: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks, you should:
questions.answerA: Sit in the cab and call for help.
questions.answerB: Exit the cab and walk away from the tracks.
questions.answerC: Motion for another driver to push your vehicle.
questions.explanation: If your vehicle gets stuck on railroad tracks for any reason, you should immediately exit the vehicle and walk away from the tracks. Contact the proper emergency authorities.

questions.question: An indicator that cargo contains hazardous materials is:
questions.answerA: The cargo is stored in cylinder tanks.
questions.answerB: The cargo is picked up from a supermarket.
questions.answerC: The cargo is packaged in cardboard boxes.
questions.explanation: Packaging can be an indicator of whether or not materials are hazardous. Cylinders and drums are often used to hold and transport hazardous materials.

questions.question: Backing with a trailer is dangerous because:
questions.answerA: It is difficult to see behind the vehicle.
questions.answerB: Most trucks do not have the ability to move in reverse.
questions.answerC: Cargo may fall out of the trailer.
questions.explanation: Backing a truck is always dangerous because the driver may not be able to see everything behind them. CMV operators should avoid backing whenever possible.

questions.question: When a tank that is divided by bulkheads is being loaded with liquid cargo, most of the weight should be placed:
questions.answerA: In the top of the tank.
questions.answerB: In the middle of the tank.
questions.answerC: In the rear of the tank.
questions.explanation: When filling a tank that is divided by bulkheads, make sure that you do not place too much weight on the front or rear of the vehicle.

questions.question: To prevent a vehicle from rolling backward when beginning to move forward from a stopped position, you should:
questions.explanation: To prevent a vehicle with manual transmission from rolling backward when you begin to move forward from a stopped position, you can partly engage the clutch before removing your foot from the brake pedal.

questions.question: What does an Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) do?
questions.answerA: It allows a vehicle's wheels to lock up.
questions.answerB: It prevents a vehicle's wheels from locking up.
questions.answerC: It makes turning a vehicle easier.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) helps prevent wheel lockup during hard braking. If ABS detects impending lockup, it reduces braking pressure to a safe level.

questions.question: When using a fire extinguisher on a fire, you should:
questions.answerA: Get as close to the fire as possible.
questions.answerB: Stand as far away from the fire as possible.
questions.answerC: Aim the extinguisher at the top of the fire.
questions.explanation: When using a fire extinguisher, you should stand as far away from the fire as possible. Aim the extinguisher at the base of the fire, not at the flames. If you are not sure which kind of extinguisher should be used on a fire, particularly a hazardous materials fire, you should wait for the firefighters to arrive and allow them to extinguish it.

questions.question: The service air line is often controlled by the foot brake and is attached to the ____ valves.
questions.explanation: The service air line carries air and is controlled by either the foot brake or trailer hand brake. The service air line is attached to relay valves, which allow the trailer brakes to be applied quickly.

questions.question: Watching the road ahead:
questions.answerA: Is more dangerous than only watching your mirrors.
questions.answerB: Does not help you drive more safely.
questions.answerC: Can help you avoid the need for sudden lane changes.
questions.explanation: Making a sudden lane change can be dangerous while driving a combination vehicle. You can avoid the need to make a sudden lange change by looking down the road for upcoming obstacles that will require you to change lanes.

questions.question: Regrooved tires are:
questions.answerA: Allowed only on the front of a bus.
questions.answerB: Allowed only on the rear of a bus.
questions.answerC: Not allowed anywhere on a bus.
questions.explanation: Regrooved, recapped, or retreaded tires are not permitted to be used on the front of a bus.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
questions.answerA: It is safe to drive on a tire that is missing one or two lug nuts.
questions.answerB: A cracked lock ring on a rim is safe if you are not driving faster than 55 mph.
questions.answerC: A missing clamp on a rim is dangerous and should be corrected.
questions.explanation: Missing clamps, spacers, studs, or lugs are dangerous, as are mismatched, bent, or cracked lock rings. Be sure your tires and rims are in good condition before operating your commercial motor vehicle.

questions.question: When filling a tank that has been separated by bulkheads, most of the weight should be in the:
questions.explanation: When filling a tank that is divided by bulkheads, you must pay particular attention to weight distribution. Avoid putting too much weight on the front or rear of the tank.

questions.question: If you press the tractor air supply control and your trailer's spring brakes do not release, you should:
questions.answerC: Turn the engine off and on again.
questions.explanation: It is important that all of a vehicle's equipment is in proper working condition before beginning a trip. If a trailer's spring brakes do not release when you push in the tractor air supply control, you should make sure the air line connections are properly attached and sealed.

questions.question: A ramp's posted speed limit:
questions.answerB: Is suitable for some vehicles, but may be too fast for a large CMV.
questions.answerC: Is just a suggestion and may be exceeded.
questions.explanation: Posted speed limits on exit and entrance ramps often show speeds that are safe to be driven by cars. However, these speed limits may be too fast for large or heavily-loaded vehicles and CMV drivers will likely need to slow down to a speed below the posted limit.

questions.question: If your brakes fail while you are traveling downhill and there is no available escape ramp, you should:
questions.explanation: If your brakes fail while you are driving downhill, you should first look for an escape ramp to stop your vehicle. If no ramp is available, you should look for an alternative place to bring your vehicle to a stop, such as an open field or side road that flattens out or turns uphill.

questions.question: One way to prevent drowsiness while driving is to:
questions.answerC: Get adequate sleep the night before the trip.
questions.explanation: Driving while fatigued can be extremely dangerous. Strategies for preventing drowsiness while driving include getting a full night's sleep before a trip; having someone ride with you; scheduling trips for times during which you are normally awake; and avoiding medications that may cause drowsiness. Exercising regularly can increase your energy levels and make you less likely to become tired while driving.

questions.question: What does a shipping paper describe?
questions.answerB: How the materials will be transported
questions.answerC: Who should accept the materials being transported
questions.explanation: Among other information, shipping papers must include a description of the specific hazardous materials being transported.

questions.question: Mirrors should be:
questions.answerC: Checked only if there is a reason to suspect a problem.
questions.explanation: When driving, you should regularly check your mirrors, both to be aware of traffic and to check for problems on your own vehicle.

questions.question: When backing with a trailer:
questions.answerA: You should not back up in a straight line.
questions.answerB: You should not correct drift until you are far off course.
questions.answerC: You should frequently pull forward to reposition the vehicle.
questions.explanation: When backing, you should pull forward to reposition your vehicle whenever needed. Drift should be corrected immediately by turning the steering wheel in the direction of the drift.

questions.question: You may be an aggressive driver if you:
questions.answerB: Slow down and maintain a reasonable following distance.
questions.answerC: Make hand gestures that could anger other drivers.
questions.explanation: Avoid being an aggressive driver by being realistic about your travel time, making allowance for delays, maintaining reasonable following distances, and not making hand gestures that could anger another driver.

questions.question: One way to avoid becoming an aggressive driver is to:
questions.answerA: Talk on your cell phone while driving.
questions.answerC: Set realistic expectations regarding travel time.
questions.explanation: To help avoid frustration, which can lead to aggressive driving behavior, you should begin a trip with realistic expectations about your travel time. Plan ahead to allow time for potential traffic delays. Other strategies to help prevent aggressive driving behavior include driving an appropriate speed and keeping a reasonable following distance; avoiding making gestures at other drivers; and keeping your hands on the steering wheel.

questions.question: What should you do if the braking system cannot build up hydraulic pressure?
questions.answerC: Hold the brake pedal down as far as it will go.
questions.explanation: If your hydraulic braking system will not build up the pressure needed to slow or stop your vehicle, there are a few possible solutions. Try shifting into a lower gear, pumping the brakes, and/or using the emergency brake.

questions.question: Convex mirrors:
questions.answerA: Cannot be used on vehicles transporting hazardous materials.
questions.answerC: Can help drivers see a larger area.
questions.explanation: Many large vehicles have curved, convex mirrors. Convex mirrors allow drivers to see a wider area than flat mirrors. However, they also make objects seem smaller and farther away than they really are.

questions.question: A tread depth of ____ should be in every major groove of a tire that is not in the front of a commercial motor vehicle.
questions.explanation: For safe operation, a commercial motor vehicle needs a tread depth of 4/32 of an inch in every major groove on the front tires, and a tread depth of 2/32 of an inch on other tires.

questions.question: While driving, a driver should:
questions.answerA: Not be concerned with what is happening on the sides of their vehicle.
questions.answerB: Be concerned with what is happening on all sides of the vehicle.
questions.answerC: Not be concerned with what is happening behind the vehicle.
questions.explanation: It is essential that you are aware of what is happening on all sides of your vehicle at all times. Scan the road ahead and make regular checks of the mirrors on both sides of your vehicle while you are driving.

questions.question: When applying your brakes, the vehicle should:
questions.explanation: Your vehicle pulling to one side or the other while you are braking can indicate trouble with the brakes.

questions.question: Be sure that your wheel bearing/seals are:
questions.explanation: During an inspection, ensure that the wheel bearing/seals are not leaking.

questions.question: Wheels with welding repairs are:
questions.answerA: Safe to be used if the repairs were done by a professional.
questions.answerB: Safe to be used if the repair seems solid.
questions.explanation: Wheels or rims that have had welding repairs are not safe for use. They should be replaced before the vehicle is taken on the road.

questions.question: The minimum acceptable tread depth for rear tires is:
questions.explanation: When inspecting your tires, verify that there is at least 4/32 of an inch of tread depth in every major groove on the front tires, and tread depth of at least 2/32 of an inch on the other tires. Tires on the same vehicle should all be the same size.

questions.question: If the emergency air line loses pressure:
questions.answerA: The Anti-Lock Braking System will activate.
questions.answerB: The service air line will activate.
questions.explanation: The emergency air line controls the emergency brakes on a combination vehicle. A loss of air pressure in the emergency line will cause the emergency trailer brakes to activate.

questions.question: Roads are especially slippery right after it begins to rain because:
questions.answerA: The water mixes with oil and grease on the road.
questions.answerB: Tires are not made to drive in wet weather.
questions.answerC: The water yet hasn't absorbed the dirt and grease.
questions.explanation: Roads are often especially slippery when it first begins to rain. Rainwater forms a slick film when mixed with oil and grease on the road surface that has not yet washed away.

questions.question: Drivers talking to passengers in their vehicle should be viewed as:
questions.explanation: Drivers who are engaged in conversation with passengers may be distracted from the task of driving. Use extra caution when driving near distracted drivers.

questions.question: If you realize you may be running late to your destination, you should:
questions.answerC: Deal with it and drive at a safe speed.
questions.explanation: To reduce the risk of developing aggressive driving behavior, you should take measures to manage your stress. One strategy to do this is to simply take a deep breath and accept your circumstances if you realize you will be late to your destination.

questions.question: When starting from a stop:
questions.answerA: A vehicle should shift to the right.
questions.answerB: A vehicle should be put into third gear.
questions.answerC: A vehicle should not roll back.
questions.explanation: To avoid hitting anything behind you, make sure that your vehicle does not roll back when you start from a complete stop.

questions.question: People working on a disabled vehicle:
questions.answerA: Are probably aware of the roadway.
questions.answerB: May be distracted by the repair and not pay attention to the roadway.
questions.explanation: Be cautious when driving near people who are working on a disabled vehicle on the side of the road. They may be focused on the repair and not paying attention to nearby traffic.

questions.question: Which of the following should not be a factor in determining the quantity of liquid to load into a tank?
questions.answerA: The degree to which the liquid will expand in transit
questions.explanation: Factors that affect how much liquid is safe to load into your tank include how much the liquid will expand in transit, the weight of the liquid, legal weight limits, and the temperature of the load.

questions.question: When coming to a stop, you should apply the brake pedal by:
questions.explanation: When stopping, you should push the brake pedal down gradually. Braking gradually will help you to maintain proper control of your vehicle.

questions.question: Load hazardous materials:
questions.explanation: Always load hazardous materials away from heat sources. Be aware of regulations on explosive or flammable materials that prohibit them from being loaded in cargo spaces with heaters.

questions.question: When leaving your vehicle:
questions.answerA: The air brakes should be applied.
questions.answerB: The parking brake should be applied.
questions.answerC: Brakes should not be applied if the vehicle is left out of gear.
questions.explanation: Parking brakes should be used whenever you park. If necessary, chock your wheels.

questions.question: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you should:
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Take the time to ensure that each handhold and railing is securely in place and safe to be used.

questions.question: When approaching a railroad crossing, a bus driver should:
questions.answerA: Stop the bus between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track.
questions.answerB: Drive cautiously, but not stop the bus unless a train is coming.
questions.answerC: Speed up to ensure the bus has momentum to cross the tracks.
questions.explanation: When approaching a railroad crossing, bus drivers should stop their vehicle between 15 and 50 feet from the nearest track and look both ways for a train. The driver should not proceed until they are certain no trains are approaching.

questions.question: To avoid a collision with a hazard on the roadway:
questions.answerA: You should always try to stop.
questions.answerB: Swerving may be a safer option than stopping.
questions.explanation: Swerving out of the way of a hazard is sometimes safer than trying to stop before reaching the hazard. You can usually turn away from something more quickly than you can come to a complete stop.

questions.question: When conducting a pre-drive inspection:
questions.answerA: The inspection report is not important.
questions.answerB: The inspection report must only be reviewed if there will be passengers in the vehicle.
questions.answerC: The previous inspection report should be reviewed, if applicable.
questions.explanation: The first step of a vehicle inspection is to review the last vehicle inspection report. Only sign the report if noted defects are certified to have been repaired.

questions.question: When inspecting your vehicle, you should check for all of the following, except:
questions.answerA: Too much air pressure in your tires.
questions.answerB: Too little air pressure in your tires.
questions.answerC: A consistent name brand across all of your tires.
questions.explanation: During a pre-trip inspection, you should verify that the air pressure is neither too low nor too high in any of your tires.

questions.question: Before operating a bus, you should make sure that the:
questions.answerA: Floor lining is easy to remove.
questions.explanation: When inspecting the interior of a bus, you must make sure everything is safe and in proper working condition. Make sure emergency exits are properly marked and easy to use.

questions.question: Shaded areas of a road:
questions.answerB: Are usually blocked from all moisture, so they cannot freeze.
questions.answerC: Will remain slick after ice has melted on other areas of the road.
questions.explanation: Because they are exposed to less sunlight and warm up more slowly, shaded areas will remain icy and slippery after ice on other areas of the road has melted.

questions.question: If a vehicle's Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) is malfunctioning:
questions.answerA: The vehicle will have no brakes.
questions.answerB: The vehicle will still be able to brake.
questions.answerC: The vehicle will likely travel faster than usual.
questions.explanation: An Anti-Lock Braking System (ABS) intervenes to reduce brake pressure if there is a risk of wheel lockup. If the ABS isn't working, the vehicle's basic braking functions are not affected. A driver should continue to drive and brake in a normal manner.

questions.question: When re-entering traffic after a bus stop, you should:
questions.answerA: Assume other drivers will allow you to merge back into traffic.
questions.answerB: Wait for a gap large enough to allow you to accelerate and merge with traffic.
questions.answerC: Allow a passenger to leave the bus and halt traffic to allow you to merge.
questions.explanation: When driving a bus, you should be mindful of the size of the gap that your vehicle will need to merge into traffic after making a stop. Wait for a gap of the necessary size to open in passing traffic before re-entering the main road.

questions.question: Radial and bias-ply tires:
questions.answerB: Should be used together on the front of a vehicle.
questions.explanation: Radial and bias-ply tires should not be used together. All wheels on a vehicle should be the same style and equally-sized.

questions.question: When transporting cargo, drivers must check the securement of the cargo every:
questions.explanation: The securement of cargo must be checked within the first 50 miles of a trip, and then again every three hours or 150 miles.

questions.question: Roof hatches on buses:
questions.answerB: Must always be closed when driving.
questions.answerC: May be locked in a partially-opened position.
questions.explanation: On a bus, it is acceptable to lock some roof hatches in a partially-opened position to provide fresh air, but this should not be made a regular practice. Remember that opening these hatches will slightly increase a bus's clearance.

questions.question: If there is a fire in your vehicle and you are not sure how to extinguish it, you should:
questions.answerB: Try douse the flames with water.
questions.answerC: Move away from the flames and wait for the firefighters.
questions.explanation: If you are not sure which method to use when putting out a fire, do not attempt to extinguish the fire on your own. Instead, wait for firefighters to arrive and let them handle it. This is especially true if you are experiencing a hazardous materials fire.

questions.question: If involved in an accident, which of the following is not recommended?
questions.answerA: Trying to move your vehicle to the side of the road
questions.explanation: When involved in an accident, you should protect the area, notify authorities, care for the injured, collect required information, and report the accident. You can lose your license for leaving the scene of an accident.

questions.question: You are especially likely to encounter strong winds when:
questions.explanation: Strong winds can make it difficult to keep a vehicle in its proper lane. Strong wind can be a particular problem when a vehicle is being driven out of a tunnel.

questions.question: Water that has collected on a roadway can cause:
questions.explanation: The risk of hydroplaning begins when water has collected on the surface of a road.

questions.question: If your brakes fail when traveling downhill, decide what to do as quickly as possible because:
questions.answerA: The longer you wait, the faster your vehicle will go.
questions.answerB: The longer you wait, the more vehicles will get out of your way.
questions.answerC: The longer you wait, the slower your vehicle will go.
questions.explanation: However you choose to deal with a brake failure on a downhill slope, it is important that you make your decision as quickly as possible. The longer you wait to act, the faster your vehicle will be moving, and the harder it will become to stop.

questions.question: When performing a pre-trip inspection and looking into the fifth wheel gap, you should:
questions.answerA: Make sure there is a gap between the kingpin and the locking jaws.
questions.answerB: Make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
questions.answerC: Make sure the locking jaws are loose.
questions.explanation: When inspecting a tractor/trailer coupling, look into the fifth wheel gap and make sure the locking jaws are fully closed around the kingpin.
